In any event, no matter what he may pretend to his constituents, the honourable member for McEwen has about as much chance of influencing the Kennett government as he has of retaining his seat at the next election—in a word, zilch, and that is probably a generous estimate. This whole exercise was nothing better than a hypocritical, unscrupulous and devious attempt at cheap political point scoring. Of course, it could be that the electors of McEwen are already awake to the member's motives so none of them have bothered to sign it. Alternatively, perhaps the honourable member is simply too embarrassed to present the petitions because, if he did, even his colleagues would be forced to question the abuse of the system. Or perhaps he is just using this exercise as a covert method of collecting names and addresses, which were provided to him in good faith, to build up data for use during the forthcoming election campaign.

Unfortunately for the present member for McEwen—but very fortunately so far as his long-suffering constituents and the nation are concerned—it does not matter what sort of databank he may be assembling, how much taxpayers' money he is willing to waste in sending out palpably misleading letters or how far he is willing to go to try to divert the electors' attention from the real issues, it will not save him on election day.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Mr Snowdon:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to participate in the debate in the Main Committee on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995. This is a very important bill which enjoys the support of all parties in the parliament. It is important to recognise that many bills do receive broad-ranging support. I think there is very great concern in the Australian community over the question of endangered species, over the question of the environment, and in many of these bills the government does receive the support of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: In Australia we have an appalling record in the area of the environment and in the area of endangered species. Australia has one of the worst records anywhere in the world. Only last year we received a terrible environmental scorecard. In the 207 years of European settlement to 1995 we have lost forever 100 species of plants and another 1,000 are vulnerable to extinction.

The CSIRO records that 15 per cent of the world's endangered plants are in Australia and animals are also threatened. It is incumbent on us, as members of parliament, to do whatever we can to make sure that those species of flora and fauna which are endangered are protected and that their long-term survival is ensured. The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill, while not directly in the area of all endangered species, is certainly a step in the right direction. As has been indicated by the shadow minister in the other place and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) as his representative in the lower house, the coalition is happy to support the government in this bill.

These are amendments to a bill which was originally introduced by a coalition government in 1982. These amendments specifically provide for a number of matters. Firstly, commercial harvests of native Australian and certain species of overseas wildlife must be conducted on a sustainable basis, with no detriment to the long-term survival of any species. Secondly, management programs and declarations for controlled specimens, for the commercial export of native plants, animal products and live fish and invertebrates, can only be approved where the appropriate state or territory legislation is in place. The requirement places the initial responsibility on individual states to ensure that any commercialisation of wildlife species will be sustainably utilised.

The amendments also provide that, in conjunction with amendments relating to management programs and controlled specimens provisions, a maximum period applies for which a management program can be approved. This amendment will close an anomaly currently existing in the act, which presently allows management and controlled specimens programs to operate indefinitely.

The bill also provides for greater flexibility in granting permits for the private importation of species, to more effectively implement appendix II of CITES—listed in schedule 2 of the principal act—relating to species which, though not endangered with extinction, could become so unless stringent regulation of trade is undertaken. The bill provides for the implementation of appendix III of CITES—in schedule 2A of the proposed amendments—which includes any species which any party identifies as being subject to regulation within its jurisdiction for the purpose of preventing or restricting exploitation and needing the cooperation of other parties in the control of trade.

The bill provides for a new offence relating to the cruel treatment of live animals being imported or exported. This provision is targeted at individuals or bodies corporate who smuggle wildlife. The new provision operates in addition to existing penalties for the import or export of wildlife without appropriate approvals.

Over the years I have often wondered that in Australia it has been quite legitimate and legal to poison large numbers of native birds and yet their exportation has been banned. I sometimes wonder about the logic of this. It is almost as though we in Australia are allowed to destroy these native species but we are not prepared to allow the rest of the world to enjoy them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally illogical.
—It is not only totally illogical; it is completely unacceptable, and it is regrettable that this adverse procedure has gone on for so long.

PARA.TAB: The bill also seeks to strengthen enforcement powers of inspectors appointed under the act, and it works towards simplifying administrative procedures, ensuring that penalties are consistent with other Commonwealth legislation. The bill provides that the maximum number of native household pet animals that may be exported is limited to two and eliminates the ownership requirements for pet birds. The existing ownership provision has proven to be difficult to establish, and not of consequence in establishing the validity of an application for a permit to export household pets.

This bill seeks to safeguard the Australian environment from the illegal introduction of exotic birds by introducing a national registration system for certain species. One of the worries is that, when exotic bird species are introduced to Australia, diseases may come with them which may then run rampant throughout the native bird population, with debilitating consequences for the future of those birds. The bill also seeks more stringent control over native wildlife species that are to be exported as inter-zoological garden transfers.

As I mentioned before, the coalition supports the broad thrust of this bill. There has also been widespread support in the Australian community for the principles of this particular bill. We must recognise that Australia is an island continent. It is the only country to inhabit an entire continent. As such, Australia is privileged to have a unique range of flora and fauna, but accompanying this privilege is a responsibility to ensure that that flora and fauna are protected. While we always enjoy seeing exotic species, it is absolutely vital to ensure that when we import those species we do not do so in a way that could severely disadvantage the continued existence of our own native species.

A number of state governments have objected to some provisions of the bill. These include the provision which requires the states to legally protect and manage the harvesting of species for export—regardless of whether, in the view of the state, there is any need to do so for conservation purposes—and the provision for the artificial imposition of a five-year time limit on management program approvals and automatic suspension of approval of management programs with unrestricted approval time limits. Other state governments have fully welcomed the bill.

There have also been some worries about the costs to states and territories of assisting in implementing schemes such as the exotic bird registration scheme and the costs to state and territory bodies in assisting in enforcing the act. I hope the government is prepared to take on board some of these concerns in the committee stage. It is important when we have a bill which is broadly supported by all parties in the parliament that, when there is the odd glitch, hiccup or problem which could easily be resolved through amendments, the government takes those on board. I am confident the government will look at these matters. I am hopeful the government will pick up the concerns expressed by people who, while they might broadly support the legislation, have problems with some elements of the detail.

Conservation groups have also pointed out that the act should be strengthened to cover the import and export of seeds, dead fish—to protect a threatened Australian species—and all live plants, including reproductive material, with the only exceptions being for environmentally benign and commonly traded species. I understand that the World Wide Fund for Nature Australia will be suggesting some changes to the legislation along those lines.

As I said at the outset, Australia really has an appalling record in the area of the environment since European settlement some 207 years ago. We have lost a hundred species of plants and another 1,000 are vulnerable to extinction. It is necessary for governments of all political colours to look at this major problem. In a country like Australia, it really is totally unacceptable that we have lost a hundred species of plants and that we have so many others which are currently vulnerable to extinction. We have similar problems with our fauna.

As a nation, we should recognise that we hold our environment in trust for future generations and that resources, wherever necessary, ought to be put into preserving endangered species of flora and fauna. I hope the government believes in this principle as well. However, after 12 years in office, the situation has not improved. I would hope that in the remaining few months of this government's term in office it is prepared to pick up the points that I have made and act on them.

It is also helpful to note that in Australia since 1950 we have lost one-third of our forests and one-half of our rainforests, and that we have major problems in areas currently under agriculture, due to salinity and erosion.

As a nation, we really do not have a lot to be proud of, but I am pleased that the parliament is debating the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill. It is important that we participate in the world community, and this bill follows our ratification of CITES, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Flora and Fauna, in 1976, and our ratification of the Convention on Biological Diversity in 1993.

This bill is an amendment to legislation originally introduced by the coalition, so for a very long time both sides of politics in Australia have been generally focused in the same direction, although in some points of detail we might differ. I ask government members to consider various concerns expressed in relation to the detail of the bill because it is absolutely vital for the future that we get this important bill right.

As has been indicated by other speakers from the opposition, we support the thrust of the bill. We have minor concerns about some aspects but we would hope that in the consideration in detail stages the government will adopt those suggestions so that a bill which we see as positive can be made even more beneficial for the future of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill is very interrelated with the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Fauna and Flora, CITES, which Australia signed and ratified during 1975-76, the Convention on Biological Diversity, which we ratified in 1993, and the Australian Nature Conservation Agency report of 1994 which stated that `the illegal importation of exotic birds has increased dramatically over the past few years'. That report indicated that the current protections and regulations are unsatisfactory. That is the germ of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), indicated, the parties are largely in accord with the need for this legislation. I do not want to reiterate at length the realities that the previous speaker indicated with regard to Australia having much to be ashamed of in previous decades. One can only note the essential misunderstanding of new colonists, new settlers, towards ecological balance in this country, the encroachment of society, of urbanisation, the introduction of exotic species—both fauna and flora—and the impact these things have had. Quite clearly, Australia has had responsibility for a large and diverse area and now has a few things to answer for.

However, it is worth noting that Australia's thrust—and, as I say, it is largely supported, I understand, by the opposition—on the international stage has been quite worth while in recent years. In the Canberra Times of 20 November 1994 it is worth repeating the thrust of an article by Peter Pockley in which he talked about Australia's role at the last CITES meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. He noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia played a prominent role in steering through the meeting more scientific criteria for future "listing" of endangered species. The tortuous process was chaired by Jim Armstrong from the West Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management—

He also noted that Australia was active in attempting unsuccessfully to list the giant Triton shell. They were unsuccessful when the criticism of some delegates showed that it was unlikely to get the required two-thirds majority. Australia played roles there with regard to the rare minke whale and also with what is becoming a vital issue—the question of the very lucrative trade resulting from the very strong demand in South-East Asia's growing economies for derivatives of tiger and rhinoceros, and similar products.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to reiterate at length the details of this bill, because many speakers have and will talk about what it specifies. But I want to give some kind of a feeling for the background against which we actually are endeavouring internationally to do something about these measures. I also want to cite a number of articles about the very serious problems that are on the horizon.
In the Age of 9 March 1995, for instance, an article talked about the question of tigers. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: In China, the world's largest exporter of manufactured tiger products, the tiger population has dropped from 2000 in the 1960s to only 50 today.

Also in the Age, on 1 December last year, an article talked about the very big issue of oriental medicines and the demand push that is resulting from the fact that oriental medicines are especially popular in China, Taiwan, South Korea and Japan. The article said:

The booming economies and personal incomes of South-East Asia have caused demand and prices to soar, lifting the international trade in wildlife products to an estimated $US6 billion-a-year ($A7.8 billion) business.

In the pharmacies of Hong Kong, a two-pound rhino horn sells for as much as $45,000. In Taiwan, a bowl of tiger penis soup (to boost virility) goes for $320, and a pair of eyes (to fight epilepsy and malaria) for $170. Powdered tiger humerus bone (for treating ulcers, rheumatism and typhoid) brings up to $1,450 a pound—

It is worth looking at this internationally. We are part of the reality that is trying to combat these types of activities and one of the provisions in this legislation goes to achieving that. It is worth looking at the realities of how the various international forces in this are interconnected. In an article in the Atlantic Monthly, in November 1994, Kenneth Brower put the interrelationship of various countries, poachers, et cetera in some perspective when he said:

Taiwan's trade in endangered wildlife extends far beyond China's borders, creating an odd international brotherhood. The illicit trade in wildlife unites Laotians hunting tigers in the jungle and good old boys poaching bears in the North American woods, black Zimbabwean rhinoceros poachers and blond members of South Africa's defense force, who reportedly have for years been funding their operations with profits from illegal diamonds, elephant ivory, and rhinoceros horn. The trade unites young Taiwanese tuna fishermen poaching the last wild reefs of Oceania for Tridacna gigas, the giant clam, with their wishful old countrymen who imagine that eating the clam's adductor muscle will give them lower blood pressure and a calmer spirit.
So this is not just a matter that affects this country alone. We know that the United States, in particular, has moved for bans on Taiwan in regard to a number of products.

PARA.TAB: On the home front, a matter of concern was the report by the TRAFFIC organisation of a survey they did of traditional Chinese medicine outlets in Sydney. They discovered that a significant portion—from recollection, it was over 60 per cent—of the products being sold there boasted, though in some cases perhaps mistakenly or fraudulently, of having rhinoceros, tiger, musk deer and other endangered species as ingredients. New South Wales legislation currently trails miserably behind the situation in Victoria where bans on such retail sales are far greater. As I understand it, New South Wales has provisions which go to the issue of wholesale distribution, but do not tackle retail issues.

CITES, the convention which is at the stem of this, does seem to be dealing with some of the big issues around the place. I have referred to the last conference in Fort Lauderdale, but at the previous meeting, in May 1994, they looked at guidelines on ranching marine turtles, procedures for the disposition of confiscated live animals and a review of a universal tagging system for the identification of crocodilian skins. It is worth noting, once again, that Australia was extremely active in the question of rhinoceros horn and tiger bone products, and that the growth of South-East Asian economies is having a very big impact as a demand push factor for these products. So while there have been a few things we have had to hang our heads about in the past, Australia has been fairly active on these matters in recent years.

This particular legislation does go to a number of aspects. It talks about management programs and declarations for the control of specimens and for the commercial export of native plants, animal products and live fish. It makes sure that the states and the territories have a very real role, and it deals with a maximum period for those management plans. I understand that one of the areas of objection is that there are maximum periods.

The legislation provides for greater flexibility in granting permits for private importation of species, to more effectively implement appendix II of CITES. Appendix II covers species which are not currently threatened with extinction but which may become so unless trade is subject to strict regulation. An export permit in relation to appendix II is required. On 23 November 1994, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) announced that the Australian population of the saltwater crocodile had been listed under this particular appendix. That is an instance of an Australian problem getting into the international debate.

There is a new offence with regard to cruel treatment of live animals being imported or exported, and it operates in addition to the existing penalties. There is, furthermore, a strengthening or furthering of powers of seizure, which at the same time goes to the questions of search of premises and conveyances, and allows inspectors the right to conduct frisk searches. I do not think that this has been subject to much criticism about going too far or limiting people's rights, given the overall problem of attempting to counter what is becoming an increasingly lucrative international trade that is attracting people coming over here to do the job themselves rather than rely on locals. We know that a significant number of people from overseas have been detained in recent years in relation to these matters.

The legislation of course looks at a national registration scheme with regard to the illegal introduction of exotic species, trying to at least understand which species are here and their numbers and possession and, therefore, to have a degree of protection in relation to the spread of diseases that could have a very debilitating effect upon our native wildlife. It also restricts the number of native household pet animals that can be taken out of the country, thereby tackling a loophole where people supposedly have these animals for one purpose but, in reality, have them essentially for commercial reasons and take large numbers out of the country.

A variety of measures in this legislation also try to do something about the burgeoning numbers of exotic birds. We have seen the kind of environmental depredation that occurs from the unfortunate accidental release of fish, but it also occurs equally with birds, and we have seen the problems that arise there. The legislation enhances the powers with regard to inspection and seeks to ensure that Australia does cooperate when other countries see a risk of their own species being endangered and therefore seek international action. Part of this legislation goes towards ensuring that Australia adheres to that CITES requirement and to making sure that, to the maximum possible extent, our laws are in conformity with that requirement. As was indicated earlier, the opposition and the government are largely in accord on the legislation, and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the words of the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) and I certainly endorse virtually everything that he said. Australia is starting to lead the world in the breeding back of many of these endangered species. In my own electorate we have projects going in that regard at the Western Plains Zoo at Dubbo, a visit to which I highly recommend to members who may not have visited that establishment.

PARA.TAB: We are not only breeding back a number of endangered Australian species such as the bilby, the mallee fowl and certain macropods but also taking on a number of overseas endangered species which we have had tremendous success with. The Przewalski horse is one where we have been so successful that it is almost embarrassing. Earlier this year we took the first consignment of horses back to the wild in Mongolia where they originated. At present there are none existing in the wild in that part of the world and the delegation that went from Dubbo with those horses was very warmly welcomed. It is a bit like the Australian kangaroo being made extinct in the wild and some overseas country breeding them up and returning them to Australia. The delegation was welcomed with open arms.

We are also about to begin a breeding program with the black rhino which will have us leading the world. The numbers of the black rhino in Zimbabwe and other African countries have plunged drastically over the last few years. Dubbo has also had success with breeding cheetahs and the zoo would like to start breeding Asiatic lions in the not too distant future, another very endangered species. I think the Gir forest in Asia has only about 200 of these left in the wild. And in the future we would like to get into breeding back tigers and perhaps African elephants. We have the only African elephants in Australasia in Dubbo.

As I said, I certainly endorse the words of the previous speaker whereby we have to look to educating and putting greater pressure on many of the Asian countries that still persist with their ignorant and barbaric quasi-medical practices. I acknowledge we have much to learn from them in other areas but that is one area that we should give some attention to.
As far as the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995 goes, the explanatory memorandum says that the purpose of the bill is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to improve import and export regulatory controls ensuring the long term conservation of native wildlife, consistent with Australia's international obligations under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) and the Convention on Biological Diversity.

The amendments provide that commercial harvests of native Australian and certain species of overseas wildlife must be conducted on a sustainable basis with no detriment to the long-term survival of any species. The amendments also provide that management programs and declarations for controlled specimens for the commercial export of native plants, animal products and live fish or invertebrates be approved only where appropriate state or territory legislation is in place. This requirement places the initial responsibility on individual states to ensure that any commercialisation of wildlife species will be sustainably utilised.

PARA.TAB: My particular comments on this bill relate to a deficiency in this area. I acknowledge that we are allowing commercial export of native plants, animal products and live fish or invertebrates but there is one glaring omission here. I believe it should also extend to certain species of native birds. We are permitted to export species of exotic birds but not native birds at all on a commercial basis. I believe there is room in this country to do so to the benefit of the environment, the economy, the farmers and, in particular, the birds that I am about to mention.

Of the several hundred species of birds that we have in this country, I am talking about only four: they are the greater Sulphur-crested cockatoo, Cacatua galerita; the galah, Cacatua roseicapilla; the little corella, Cacatua sanguinea; and the long-billed corella, Cacatua tenuirostris. I believe they are in much larger numbers now than was the case before European settlement in this country. This is because of our crops and water storage systems. They have bred in plague proportions, particularly around areas where we grow summer crops. The habitats of these birds have also expanded vastly. In some areas, they are present in hundreds of thousands—almost plague proportions. They are particularly a nuisance when farmers sow crops, around the time of harvest and also when the grain is being stored.

I will briefly expand on that. It is very frustrating trying to sow crops when these birds flock in great numbers and eat the grain as it is being put into the soil. The farmers virtually have to ride shotgun on their tractors to get the grain into the ground. When the seed is sown, they stay in their thousands and scratch it out. Near harvest time, when the grain ripens, the flocks emerge and almost darken the sky. They eat the grain, whether it be sorghum, sunflower or whatever. When the grain is being stored, they come in their tens of thousands and try to get it.

In the natural environment, these particular species become very aggressive when they are in these sorts of numbers. They drive out other birds and destroy their nesting sites. In itself, this upsets the delicate avian ecological balance that exists along many of our rivers. I believe that should be acknowledged. In addition to that, because they breed in such numbers due to the fact that they feed on the crops, they defoliate and ringbark many magnificent trees and end up killing them. This is also something that we should take into consideration. Of course, they do other damage of a lesser nature. They attack and damage powerlines. From time to time, many people in rural areas will also have the cables from their TV antennas chewed through by these birds.

There are certain things you are allowed to do to overcome these problems. I will just run through a few of them. Shooting these birds is one of the most common things. It is not actually the killing of the birds, as such—because they can only be shot one at a time, and we are talking about thousands of birds—but the noise of the shooting that drives them off. However, they eventually get used to the noise and shooting becomes not only expensive but also largely ineffective. Scarecrows are also used, particularly on orchards. While they can be effective in some circumstances, their use is certainly limited on broadacre crops.

Various other methods have been used to deter these birds, such as using high pitched sounds, but, again, these have limited use. The most effective method of all is trapping. I am not talking about mist nets, which are illegal, but ground nets whereby a bird is put in a cage as a decoy, other birds assemble in the area and then the ground trap is triggered, springs over the birds and traps them underneath.

That is all very well, but you are then confronted with the problem of what to do with these birds. You can put them in cages, as the National Parks and Wildlife Service encourages you to do, and drive them out to a distant place and release them. But unless you travel hundreds of kilometres, what do these birds do? They fly back again within a short period of time. Running them around the country is an expensive thing to do, and it is limited with the numbers—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just moving the problem elsewhere.

—Indeed, you are moving the problem to someone else. That is unsatisfactory. Mrs Kirner, the ex-Premier of Victoria, when she was environment minister in that state, advocated putting the birds in 44-gallon drums and gassing them. That does not excite me at all. It is not something that we want to do.

PARA.TAB: The birds can be gathered up and sold on the domestic market. But there is little scope for this method of disposal. The domestic market is very limited. Once you have sold, at the most, a few hundred of these birds, the market is flooded.

The birds can be killed outright by clubbing them to death, or by walking around on top of the nets and crushing them with your boots. That is legal, but I find it inhumane and horrifying, as well as being an incredible waste.

There is a very logical answer as to what we can do with these birds: that is, to sell them overseas. We are only talking about sending them to acceptable countries, and I will deal with that later. For some reason the National Parks and Wildlife Service finds overseas sale unacceptable. If you look at it from the point of view of the birds, it would be much more preferable to be sold to a wealthy American and be pampered in a proper aviary than to be crushed to death in Australia. If I was a bird I know which option I would take.

It is also legal to poison these birds. It would be all very well if you could use 1080, but that is quite limited in its application. Usually, farmers will use organophosphorus poisoning on grain trails, which results in a very painful and inhumane death for the birds. Again, that is something that I find quite distasteful and unacceptable.

These birds can be legally disposed of in their thousands—or illegally in some circumstances—but apart from the undesirable features that I have mentioned, many non-target birds are also picked up. I have reports of 15 to 20 species of non-target birds being poisoned when this method is used. Whichever way you look at it, selling these birds legally on the export market would be the way to go. But the government will not allow it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It makes a lot of sense.

—Indeed, I think it makes a lot of sense. You can export non-native birds from this country now; they are bred from exotic species imported into Australia. But you are not allowed to export native birds. I cannot see the logic of it at all. There is a bureaucratic mechanism already in place which would ensure that only four species of birds would be sent out. It would not open the way for endangered species to be sent out.

PARA.TAB: We are allowed to export native animals. Why is it that we cannot export native birds when the need is clearly there? We even export sensitive native animals, such as koalas. I support the government in doing that. I know some people oppose it, but if we send koalas to Japan we know very well that the Japanese will look after them to the very best of their ability. They will devote enormous amounts of money for research on koala diseases. In fact, Japan spends more money on research into the diseases of koalas—which is urgently needed—than Australia would spend in a generation. It is quite proper that we allow koalas to go out of this country, as long as very strict controls are maintained.

I look at the export mechanism that is in place now for non-native birds. There are about 10 costly procedures that have to be gone through. Anyone who is an exporter has to have a certified quarantine establishment licence. The overseas importer of our birds has to have a certified quarantine establishment licence also, which makes sure that these birds do not end up in some sort of backyard, shonky place where they would be maltreated—not something any of us would approve of. The Australian exporter has to have a CITES licence, a Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora licence, and this is issued by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and there is a cost to that. It used to be $40; I do not know what it is now.

All avian species destined for overseas must be inspected by a qualified government veterinary officer within 24 hours of being sent out of this country. As a result of that inspection, a health certificate is issued. A numbered seal is then attached to the cage opening and that seal cannot be broken until the bird has been exported. The identification of the avian species, to make sure the right ones are in there, is done by non-government bodies at no cost to the government. Since 1950, this has been available to exporters as a free service by ornithologists who come from either the Australian Museum or an A-class zoological garden, and they issue a document. In this regard, there has not been one case of fraud in this country that I know of in all the time that this system has been operating.

The airports have holding facilities for avifauna, which are the responsibility of the airline companies, and the birds are housed according to a code of practice laid down by the International Air Transport Association. The exporter must sign one of these IATA forms indicating that all the packaging and health standard requirements are met. One must have an export customs clearance, which, again, involves more money, but is a further check; and one must have a customs recheck for any anomalies. Customs check that the applicant is a signatory to the CITES agreement.

As well as that, upon arrival in the importing country, the overseas country, the consignment is met at the airport by an animal quarantine official who inspects the species and examines the seal on the cages. The birds are not allowed to be released until they go to the proper, licensed, private, quarantine facility. So there is a very good mechanism, a very thorough mechanism, in place now. Nobody can say that, if we opened up to exporting native birds out of this country, it would be done in an improper manner.

There are other advantages as well as that, of course, apart from its being better for the birds that are otherwise killed, better for the farmers and better for the economy. The government could earn royalties from this. These birds are being smuggled out of the country now, and are making from $5,000 to $20,000 in some instances. Even if we charged $100 for these birds, here is an export industry that we could have worth tens of millions of dollars to Australia. It would also, I believe, have the other advantage of taking the pressure off smuggling—not only smuggling other species out of Australia, but smuggling some of these rare parrots out of Indonesia and out of the north part of South America. Countries such as Suriname have some very rare parrots indeed, and it is a tragedy that these birds are being smuggled into places in America where there are wealthy bird collectors who want these spectacular birds. They could be having Australian birds, all legal and above board. Hopefully, that would replace some of this smuggling that takes place elsewhere. I commend this suggestion of the government. It could perhaps take it on board and trial it for a couple of years. I am sure it would work well, as it works well with every other species of animal that we export from this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too rise to speak in support of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995. It is, from my point of view, rather pleasing to hear opposition members supporting the bill in this place, and I note that in the Senate in September Senator Kemp from Victoria also rose to speak in support of this bill. It is something that concerns everyone regardless of where our political affiliation lies, and that is very important.

PARA.TAB: This bill itself forms part of Australia's commitment to further honouring two important conventions on the protection of wildlife: the 1976 Convention on Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, CITES, and the 1993 Convention on Biological Diversity, both of which Australia ratified.

The purpose of this bill is to improve the controls our authorities are able to exercise and to ensure the long-term conservation of wildlife in Australia. In a nutshell, it will strengthen our power to prevent trade exploitation which endangers any species. Whilst no authority in the world can actually stamp out some forms of exploitative trade, this bill goes a long way towards stamping out certain practices, and that in its turn is another step towards protecting those species which are already threatened with extinction.

I would like to give some background on the nature of this trade. Figures compiled last year by the international monitoring agency TRAFFIC indicate that every year some five million birds, 25,000 primates and 10 million reptiles are taken from the wild to be sold elsewhere. Their fate, as we all know, can be terrible. Millions of birds undoubtedly end up bound and stuffed into things like suitcases, where, we have seen via our televisions, they die from shock and asphyxiation or dehydration.

I recall a few cases recently where Australian customs officers have found birds in exactly this condition. For example, at the end of last year a particularly pathetic attempt to smuggle several Major Mitchells and a gang-gang cockatoo out of the country made the headlines in Sydney. The birds had been tightly bound with electrical tape and had not been fed or watered before they were stuffed into plastic pipes. Three were already dead. The rest were in shock and probably some of those did not survive either.

Birds are not the only victims of this type of treatment. Snakes and lizards have been found crammed half-frozen into empty video cassettes. On one occasion Northern Territory customs officers seized 58 blue-tongue lizards packed in an air express box about 30 centimetres wide. I suppose it is fair to say that any creature worth tens of thousands of dollars in another country is a potential victim of such treatment.

I would like to bring to the attention of the chamber an example of victimisation of creatures from Tasmania. I spoke in the House last year about the Tasmanian sea dragon from the south-eastern waters of Tasmania. Sea dragons have been systematically caught, slaughtered, then dried and processed to be sold as an aphrodisiac in the Asian region. This in itself is an exploitation of a minor species. The Tasmanian sea dragon is a very rare minor species and, if nothing is done to protect it in its natural habitat, it will become extinct, as so many others have in the past. It is inherent in our duties as members of this parliament to put into place protection via legislation to assist these types of animals to be saved. And it is not only animals, of course; it is plant life as well.

Whilst reports of this type of smuggling and desecration of our wildlife are disturbing, I am pleased to be able to say that Australia is taking a tougher stance against it. This bill in itself includes an amendment which makes the cruelty I have described in itself an offence, and anyone found guilty of this offence may find themselves behind bars for up to two years.

As well, the bill makes it easier for customs officials to frisk suspect persons and it removes the defence of not having the animals directly in their possession. It should be noted, too, that the introduction of the bill coincides with the peak nesting season for many of our native birds. I trust that we will continue to get bipartisan support so as to let this have an impact now and in the future.

Exporting birds or other wildlife is not the only issue here. The government is also concerned about the risks associated with exotic birds getting into this country. There is a great potential for exotic birds to form self-sustaining colonies which could pose a real threat to the native wildlife populations of plants and animals in Australia, as well as to our aviculture industry.

It is understood that since 1992, when a ban was lifted on exotic birds being brought into the country, some 50 new species of birds have been introduced. There is a major question here as to whether or not they remain in captivity. One would hope that they do and that they have, but that is another matter.

The bill addresses this concern with the introduction of a national exotic birds registration scheme. It has been developed in close consultation with the aviculture industry, with bird keepers and with the states and territories. It is hoped that this scheme will totally incorporate an inventory of all exotic birds in Australia, and that it will enable us to effectively manage exotic bird populations and check against new ones coming in.

It provides a national focus that allows some flexibility to the states and territories to impose additional measures if they see fit to do so. This scheme will assist the legal trade in exotic birds. In so doing it will further discourage the illegal trade which I described earlier.

Obviously, the scheme will need to be assessed for effectiveness some way down the track. To this end, an advisory committee to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories will be established to advise on and monitor the scheme. I have every confidence that it will prove to be an invaluable component of the country's conservation strategy. If we do not get into the business of conserving our wildlife and our plant life now, there will be no such wildlife and plant life for future generations. We have to be responsible now and put all types of restrictions and laws into place for protection of the future.

I should like to reiterate that the bill does not centre on the trade of birds alone. It provides provisions to crack down on illegal traders of any species, be it plant, animal, fungus or whatever. The bill also extends the offence of possession of illegally imported animals and plants to the progeny of those specimens. It tightens the regulations relating to the import of hunting trophies. It also increases inspectors' powers to stop, search and question suspected traffickers.

One of the things that the CITES convention did was to formally recognise the need for international cooperation if we are ever to have any real impact on the illegal trade of wild flora and fauna. Australia already has an excellent international reputation for its conservation stance, although in this area it is not good enough to rest on our laurels.

The bill before us prohibits the importing of wildlife specimens contrary to the laws of a foreign country, thereby assisting other countries to enforce their laws and maintain a global focus on the conservation effort. Without such cooperative efforts, any attempt to stem the international smuggling industry would be doomed. Australia is playing a leading role in fighting that industry.

As I said earlier, the purpose of this bill is to improve the controls our authorities are able to exercise to ensure the long-term conservation of wildlife. In a nutshell, it will strengthen our powers to prevent any trade exploitation which endangers any species from Australia. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to support the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill because I think it improves the legislation. However, in my view there are still a lot of areas which could be improved. This legislation covers an area in which people have become emotional and irrational. To give an example of that, the government of the day, which was the Liberal-National party government, in 1960 decreed that there would be a total ban on the export of all Australian fauna. It was decreed that on 1 January it would all stop.

PARA.TAB: I was working for a company that sold animals to zoos throughout the world, which operated out of Adelaide at the time. The main Australian fauna exported was kangaroos. The company carried its own insurance, so it had to make sure conditions were good. If there was a five per cent loss on a shipload of kangaroos to America, all hell would break loose. The company really did look after its product. That was not surprising because it was getting, in 1958 money, #125 per animal delivered live to New York. It was a very lucrative business. This business was stopped overnight on 1 January 1960.

Towards the end of 1958, we opened up kangaroo meat exports from Australia. That meat was sold to Germany. It was sold as Australian venison—and kangaroo meat does taste a bit like venison, although the grain structure is very different. In the first year, that business saw the demise of probably some 100,000 kangaroos. They were just slaughtered. That business grew until, overnight, the Germans stopped the import because of the appalling hygiene standards we were then applying. That was an indictment of the greed and lack of care that went into an industry that could have been very beneficial to Australia. Incidentally, it dropped the price of meat from seven pence to tuppence a pound.

That shows the stupidity of the situation where a government acts at the behest of pressure groups—as governments still do today—to stop export by an industry in which there was very good control, control which was forced by economics. The companies did not pay if the product arrived dead. That led to the establishment of an industry where the product was exported dead. Apparently, the logic was that exporting kangaroos live depleted the fauna, whereas exporting them dead did not. I thought then that that was Liberal Party logic—something which I have never been able to fathom. Unfortunately, the same intellectual rigour seems to have affected my own government.

A couple of things in this legislation need to be looked at. There is a section where, for exporters who propose to export native animals, the government can dictate that they must get an ongoing commitment from the people overseas as to what the animals are going to be used for and how they are going to be looked after—that is when they are exporting from Australia. On the other hand, it is also quite clear in the legislation that once the animals go overseas we have absolutely no control over them. It seems to me to be a little odd. If there can be no control of it, what is the point of getting these sorts of commitments?

Another thing I see—just a small thing—is that we are going to limit the number of birds taken out as family pets to two. I am not sure from the bill whether it is two per person or two per family. If it is two per family it is pretty absurd. Also, what sort of bird is this about? If it is a galah, a green budgerigar or a cockatiel, they are in such large numbers in Australia that it presents no threat whatsoever. I remember making a speech in this parliament, probably 15 years ago, which just shows how little things change. I recall seeing on the Nullarbor, shortly after we had actually banned the export of live fauna, 20,000-gallon tanks full of drowned budgerigars—20,000 gallons of stinking budgerigar soup. It is absurd to think there can be any threat to budgerigars by allowing their export.

What happens to a family? They might have three children. They have got a pet bird each. What do you do? Do you have one bird put down, along with the child? It is quite silly and to have it in that form, where the limit is two, is quite absurd. There should be some ability to apply commonsense. I know legislators do not apply commonsense because we see in the bill here that under one offence—I tried to find it this morning while I was doing a radio interview; as you get older you are not so good at mental dexterity—we are going to apply to illegally importing or exporting fauna 10,000 penalty points, which equates to 10 years in gaol. I think that was the figure. Where is the logic in this? You can kill people and get less than that.

I know that, in the minds of many people, birds are people too. But I think we do have to have some rationality in this. I am concerned that this bill, like the fisheries acts in the states, particularly in Western Australia, gives to fauna investigators powers of search which seem to exceed the powers of the police. We have seen in Western Australia grave concern about the abuse of these powers by the fisheries department—at, I might add, the behest of the police. We should be looking at that and writing into the legislation some discretion.

Quite frankly, if the family has a fetish for green budgerigars or galahs it does not matter how many they export, how many they take out of the country. Some people would say the more the better. The situation is that, while we have these draconian penalties for exporting fauna, we are at the same time poisoning those same birds. You can get a permit to do this and it happens around some of the irrigation areas. In reality, are we concerned about the illegal export of birds, or are we concerned about looking good in the eyes of the world and meeting our CITES obligations?

There is absolutely no doubt that when there was a controlled export of fauna from Australia—that was prior to 1 June 1960—those people that had permits to be out in the field trapping birds took the business very seriously. If they found people out there trapping birds illegally, they would report them and they would be on the spot. It was very well policed and there was great control on it. Now the legal trappers are illegal so they are not out there. The illegal trappers are out there because they do not mind being illegal, and the birds are exported with great cruelty and they can accept enormous loss of life.

I can remember that, for instance, in 1959 the company I worked for got an order from Germany for 15 tiger snakes. Wages at the time were about #6 10s a week and the company was paying me #5 a tiger snake—just money for old rope! I could go down to the south-east of South Australia and I could get that number of tiger snakes in a weekend. I do not believe I did the fauna of Australia any lasting harm by exporting those. There are still plenty of tiger snakes there. But it became a very serious crime.

We have to have some balance in the legislation, because if we are going to apply these rules rigorously to animals that are not rare it is going to call into disrepute the whole system. Some birds should be protected. Some birds are rare. I would certainly object to the export of any night parrots, if we could find any. Even Bourke parrots are relatively rare, although I have seen them in large numbers. But other birds are simply readily available.

In this legislation, we are not going to allow the export of any animal unless it can be readily bred in captivity. That seems to me to be commercially rather stupid. Australia does have some unique birds which have a market in the world, and their uniqueness puts a substantial price on them. If we were to have a controlled market of these birds—and, I would suggest, in many cases it would simply allow for the export of birds bred in captivity—we would have a market such that if we applied a royalty to the sales at 100 per cent of the sale cost we would get a considerable sum, in the region of $30 million or $40 million a year, for the government, which could be earmarked for national parks.

The reality with national parks is that, by and large, we mark them on maps and do nothing about them at all. There is no management applied at all. People who live next to them get the consequences. One cannot do anything about controlling vermin in these national parks, so the problem resides with the people who have properties adjoining them. It is a problem.

I saw in Broome that we had a world-class zoo—set up by Lord McAlpine—that could not possibly ever replace its capital value. However, if that zoo had been allowed to sell birds that were bred in captivity, it would have been viable and we would have kept a very valuable asset for the community there. How, in anybody's name—I was going to invoke God—does it deplete the fauna, or put fauna at risk, to export aviary bred birds?

To export from Australia an exotic bird—exotic in the view of the rest of the world—that is hard to breed is commercially very sensible, because it means that there is going to be an ongoing market for those birds. The reason that the price of these birds is very high overseas is that export is illegal. It is often done with great cruelty. If we were to allow the export of these birds on a controlled basis, the price would fall, but it would still be very viable. When we had wheat farmers going broke, if they could have got permits for a few hundred galahs or white cockatiels—which are in plague proportions—it would have made them viable. It would have saved them.

Incidentally, what has happened in Australia with a lot of these parrot types is that we have cut down their habitat. We have cleared it for wheat farming. The remaining trees get attacked by the birds. The strategy of the bird is to ringbark around its hole, so that it becomes very hard and the goanna cannot get its claws in. The goanna is one of the main predators. He cannot get a foothold there. It does not seem to worry cats much, but that is the bird's natural defence mechanism. When there are a lot of birds nesting in a tree they effectively end up ringbarking the tree, because they all make holes around their own little nests.

At the same time, we have exponentially expanded the food supply. We planted the wheat for them. They have had a massive increase in food and a reduction in living accommodation. We have seen a big increase in numbers of these birds. I do not think there is any doubt that, in many areas, numbers of these birds have increased over time—just as, I might add, numbers of kangaroos have increased over time.

When I first went to the Nullarbor in 1960, there were no kangaroos on the Nullarbor. Here you had millions of acres of rolling grass plain, ideal kangaroo country. Why were there no kangaroos? For the same reason there were never any Aboriginals out there—there was no surface water. They could not exist without water. In a good season you would get a few reds come through. We put bores down, and within four years of our putting the water out there you could shoot 100 kangaroos a night. Now you will find the Nullarbor is home to kangaroos, both the red, Megaleia rufa, and the western grey, Macropus fuliginosus.

That is the stupidity of it. Just as the fact that there were no Aboriginals out there will not stop native title claims, the fact that the kangaroo is in abundance will not stop the emotional nonsense you get in cities, where people say, `We don't see any kangaroos now.' Of course they do not; the kangaroos have been built out. But there is absolutely no doubt that the number of kangaroos in Australia is greater today than it has been at any time in Australia's history. The emotional nonsense that goes on in this trade is quite bizarre.

Here we have, in kangaroo, the finest and strongest leather, by weight, in the world—the ideal leather for orthopaedic shoes. Australia should be the world's capital in the construction of orthopaedic shoes. But then, I suppose you must get realistic and realise that orthopaedic shoes would only benefit human beings. We seem to be, in present-day thinking, fairly low on the scale of things.

I do support the bill. It has amended some silly provisions. It has made things better but there are a couple of points that should be looked at. I also think that, as a nation, we should be looking at what is good for the fauna, what is good for the country, what is good in our own national interest, and looking at relaxing the export of some of these species on a commercial basis. I do not mind if that money is earmarked for national parks. We put these national parks on the maps because it makes the people in Sydney and Melbourne feel good, but in reality very little is done with them. In Western Australia, for instance, we have the massive Rudall River National Park. Why is it there? Back in the 1960s there was a bit of pressure in Perth on Sir Charles Court and he said, `I'll give `em conservation. I'll give `em a national park.' It was a national park half the size of Tasmania, in the middle of Western Australia.

Nobody had a look at it, nobody did any mineralogy. In fact, it was put over mining leases where companies had actually gone out with mining leases granted by the government and had discovered uranium, in this case, at Rudall River. We then had to make a very hurried correction and make the national park bind around their leases.
This has also been used by the Greens. I say with all sincerity that the Greens pose a far greater threat to this country than the combined Liberal-National party.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very serious threat.
—It is a threat that cannot be underestimated.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—The member for Kalgoorlie needs no encouragement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that the legislation is there has helped to stop the export of this product, which has been very good for the national interests of all Australians. But, as I have said in this place before, sadly Melbourne and Sydney will not realise the importance to this country of export earnings until they have stopped it, and when they do they will be the first to complain. I do not know what we do about that: education does not seem to be working; the media remains ignorant; you get this enormous, ill-informed, emotional backlash from these places. It is true that both major parties know that, if they can win big in Melbourne and Sydney, real Australia does not matter. Short of nuking them I see no solution but we do not have the wherewithal to do that at this stage. I am warning you that the time will come.

PARA.TAB: In short, this bill is a move in the right direction. I do think there is more we could do. We should have a look at it in a very sensible light. We should have more regard to real welfare of the animals. This is an area where we could commercialise to the benefit of looking after these things and of applied money. There is absolutely no doubt that research that is needed in these areas is very short of money, and here is one area where, by licensing the export of that fauna, we could provide a lot of money for that. I recommend that the government—a government, any government—some time in the future has the courage to reject the emotional impact and pressure it is subjected to and looks at this from the point of interest of the birds.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you might be able to help me. The Parliamentary Secretary has left me some notes to respond. Am I in order to do that now?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—There is no reason why we cannot allow the minister to report now.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for the confusion and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon) apologises for his absence but he asked me to respond to some of the points that have been raised in the debate.

PARA.TAB: I know he would want to thank honourable members who have taken part in the debate for the support that they have expressed for the amendment bill. I take it that the remarks of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) were broadly in support in the context of a quite challenging speech and my only regret is that the tiger snake and the green budgerigars were not here to exercise a right of reply.

The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995 provides a raft of key reforms to the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 in furthering the commitment of the government to the conservation and management of our biodiversity. The amendments will enhance the extent to which Australia discharges its responsibilities under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora and the Convention on Biological Diversity. It further provides an improved administrative framework for the Australian Nature Conservation Agency to service its client groups, to strengthen measures against illegal wildlife trafficking and to support a national and international approach to conservation and management of biodiversity.

I understand the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) and the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) raised a number of issues concerning the importation of fish. Those members will be comforted to know that the government is actively addressing these matters. Fish product importation issues are now being considered on a broader front by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins). The Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture has set up a task force to address the problems associated with the importation of fish produce into Australia.

The task force comprises representatives of Commonwealth and state governments and industry. The Australia Nature Conservation Agency, under the environment, sport and territories portfolio, is also represented on the task force. The task force will be expected to report to the ministerial council and to the Agriculture Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand.

During the debate, members also made reference to the importation of plants. The government recognises that trade in plants is of significance as the worldwide movement of plants over the last two centuries has allowed the introduction of large numbers of environmental weeds. Appropriate controls need to be in place to adequately address environmental concerns but we must ensure that we do not compromise our trade policies in relation to the GATT and the World Trade Organisation or unnecessarily restrict bona fide imports of nursery, horticultural or agricultural crop species.

Processes are already in train to address the import issue through the development of a national weed strategy. I understand there are a number of recommendations arising from the weed strategy. These include the development of improved screening systems for assessment of the weed potential and environmental risk for all proposed new plant imports and the need to finalise guidelines for identifying and evaluation of weeds of national significance.

As members will appreciate, the issue is not straightforward. The government recognises the importance of the issue and is addressing it in a structured and consultative manner. It is vital that our wildlife laws and consultative processes address the demands that are being placed on and will continue to be placed on our wildlife resources. In closing, the government believes that the amendments demonstrate our commitment to a secure environment for the future.
Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the bill be reported to the House.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 27 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to initiatives announced in the 1995-96 budget and to provide for cost supplementation of grants for 1995 and 1996 in accordance with established policy. The bill proposes an extension of the early literacy program to 1996. This program provides grants to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling. Some $6.666 million is to be made available to government schools and $2.208 million to non-government schools in the year.

PARA.TAB: As in 1995, there will be special emphasis on children disadvantaged by low socioeconomic circumstances. Another budget initiative reflected in the bill is a proposal for a new program of grants to non-government special schools to assist students with disabilities to make the transition to mainstream school education or to pursue further training or employment. An amount of $3.22 million is to be provided in 1996.

The final budget decision reflected in the bill is the cessation of new projects in 1996 under the gender equity program and the gifted and talented children program, and of staff training, development and community liaison under the hostels for rural school students program. These initiatives have either served their purpose or are now more appropriately the responsibility of other bodies.

The bill also provides for supplementation of capital and recurrent grants to reflect movements in costs. For 1995, this means an additional $7 million for capital purposes and $55 million for recurrent programs and, for 1996, an additional $56 million for recurrent programs and a further $7 million for capital programs. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I discuss the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, Deputy Speaker Andrew, I will again place on the public record my objection to a bill talking about educating young Australians being presented in the Main Committee. This is not meant with any disrespect to you, Sir. The bill that I heard debated prior to this was the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill, and it is an utter disgrace that this debate is not being held in the main chamber. As I have said before, it is also an utter disgrace that this House rises at 8 o'clock. If that is the reason we are in this Main Committee, then heaven help democracy in this country.

PARA.TAB: My view is that there are very many people who come into this House and who go into the main chamber to hear matters that they want to hear discussed, or else they are here on a visit to see what the business of the House is; yet we are here, stuck in this appalling little room, discussing matters of great importance to all of us and, indeed, denying a large number of people the opportunity to hear the business of this House. It is an utter disgrace. I am not blaming the government: there was a bipartisan approach to this. I have said all the way along that it was ill-informed decision by all those involved, and I again place that on the public record. Having said that, I will not pursue it any further.

It gives me great pleasure to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995. This bill gives effect to a number of measures announced in the 1995-96 budget. As a result, no new grants will be provided in 1996 to the program to improve the learning experience of girls, nor to special projects in connection with non-government rural school student hostels, nor to the program to assist gifted and talented children.

The bill, however, does provide an extension of the early literacy program to 1996, as well as establishing a new program of grants for projects of non-government special schools to assist students with disabilities to make the transition to mainstream school education or to pursue further training or employment. Of course, other measures were announced by Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) during his speech, but I will not take up the time of the House to repeat them.

This bill in many ways is a blueprint of the government's plans for school funding in the future. Although the coalition will not be opposing this bill, we do have real concerns about the direction in which the government is preparing to take school funding. There are some measures in the legislation which the coalition welcomes, but we are concerned about the timing of the announcement. Those measures include the additional $8.9 million to extend the early literacy program, and the additional $3.2 million for the commencement of the transition support for special schools to assist students with disabilities.

I would like to make a few comments on students with disabilities. Let there be no doubt that the coalition is committed to ensuring improved access to education for students with disabilities. Students with disabilities have as much right as able-bodied students to a first-class education. These students and their parents do not want pity or platitudes. What they want is a genuine commitment by governments to ensure access to a quality education. That is why this long overdue announcement by the government is welcomed by the opposition. The issue of funding for transitional support for disabled students has long been an issue and I have been informed by many, in both the government and the non-government school sector, that they have long lobbied the government for funding. Although this is a welcome measure, we must question the motives of a government which announces such an issue in the budget prior to an election. This is typical of Labor in campaign mode and one can only question its genuine commitment to disabled students.

The government's long overdue initiatives on literacy are also welcomed. However, this government has been there for over 12 years and we can rightly question its ability and its commitment to deliver proper literacy standards. I have documented in the past all the so-called initiatives that we have had over the last 12 years of Labor. I will not take up the time of the chamber and repeat the details, except to say that in October 1995 we had a minister who, when asked about the state of literacy in Australia, replied that he did not know. He did not know that 25 per cent of Australian children in Australian schools are battling literacy problems.

I would ask the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training what his literacy survey is showing, and when he will be tabling the results for us to see. If the minister wishes to be taken seriously in this debate, then I challenge him to table the results of the literacy survey before the next election even if they are only interim results. If he has the courage of his convictions that the literacy levels in this country are at respectable standards, then this should not be a cause for embarrassment.

It would appear that I am not the only one who has grave concerns about the current state of Australia's literacy levels. One of Australia's leading authors, Mem Fox, has described the level of literacy amongst Australian schoolchildren as `not up to scratch'. Not only is she an author, but Mem Fox is an associate professor of teacher education at Flinders University and is a well-known exponent of what has become known as the whole language learning approach to literacy. There is no doubt that Mem Fox is a highly respected member of the community and an informed voice in the education arena. Her views should be taken seriously, especially when she warns that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . children must have literacy basics in order to be able to function as literate members of our society, and these must be explicitly—
I repeat `explicitly'—
taught over and over again.

What Mem Fox is actually saying is that in 1995 Australian schoolchildren are not being taught the basics of English—reading and writing. What sort of a society have we become where the basics in reading and writing have been overlooked to the extent that we need to have them as a national focus again?

PARA.TAB: Not only are parents, teachers, authors and academics expressing concerns about the declining literacy standards in Australia but so, I might say begrudgingly, is the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. In a speech to the House on 9 March this year, the minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I would be the first to admit that the work we have done in literacy has not been completely successful.

This is an admission of defeat on the part of the minister. If this has been the result of so-called initiatives in the past, what hope can we have that present initiatives, such as the early literacy program, will be a success? What guarantee can the minister give us that in 12 months time we will not be here again being told that the past programs in literacy have not been a complete success?

PARA.TAB: As I have said before, what is needed is a national strategy to raise standards of literacy and numeracy along the lines of those being developed by many of the states. Such a strategy will allow better identification of those students who are in need, and a better direction and focus of resources for those students. It is important that these resources are targeted to the acquisition of literacy competencies in the early years of schooling, for this, in many ways, is a prerequisite for later success in education and, indeed, in life generally. A recent report by the Schools Council entitled Resources and accountability: Commonwealth funding scenarios for government primary schools 1996-2000 also has some very interesting points to make about literacy. The report found:

SPEECH.PARA: It is widely acknowledged that people lacking effective English literacy are likely to be severely disadvantaged in terms of employment opportunities.

It is simply not good enough for the minister to concede on the literacy front when the consequences are so high for many young Australians. If a low level of literacy is detrimental to a student's future, why has it taken Labor 12 years to act?

PARA.TAB: My friend and colleague the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) is in the chamber today. We have been actively involved in a parliamentary inquiry into truancy. As the report has not been released, I will be mindful of what I say. But I am sure that he would agree with me that the issues of literacy and the consequences for illiterate children have been raised with us right across Australia. They are matters of deep concern to both of us.

Literacy is not the only area where the government has let down the students of Australia. Rural education has long been an area of neglect by this Labor government. Nowhere is neglect more evident than in the proposal to end certain aspects of the rural hostels program. This program provided an important opportunity for access to education for many country students. The objects of the program were to increase access to schools for students from isolated rural areas by improving the effectiveness of the operation of hostels for rural students.

The recurrent funding in this program was used for staff training and development, management advice, frameworks for information exchange, office equipment, recruitment of staff and promotion and support services for students. The government was very proud of this program. On page 21 of its education and training policy for the 1993 federal election it boasted that:

SPEECH.PARA: A Labor Government will provide recurrent funding of over $3.5 million over the next three years to support existing and developing hostels for rural school students.
But this was not just an idle commitment. The 1994-95 Department of Employment Education and Training `Programs Book', at page 19, refers quite explicitly to funding for the rural hostels program:
. . . in 1994, the allocation for this program is $1.6m. A further $1 million will be provided each year in 1995 and 1996.

This is funding that the non-government rural hostels have budgeted for; they made plans based on that funding. Now, with this legislation, we find this is not the case. The bill will not allocate the promised $1 million to that sector. The legislation is a clear breach of promise by the government, and exposes just how deceitful it was towards the rural sector at the last election.

PARA.TAB: I have been advised that many of these hostels will now have to look for alternative sources of funding, with many unaware of where this funding will come from. I understand that this decision was made with no warning, no consultation and no respect for those in the rural sector. The government has well and truly left the rural hostels in the lurch by promising $3 million, yet delivering only $2 million. One million dollars may not seem a lot to the minister, but it makes a hell of a difference to those in the rural sector who are already struggling to make ends meet.

What makes this decision all the more heartless is that is has been done at a time of high levels of rural unemployment, and at the time of one of the worst droughts in Australia's history. The minister is simply not aware of the hardships and the struggles that rural Australia is going through.

On July 6 this year the minister actually came to my electorate talking of the need for an educational vision for rural Australia. Attending a conference of the Society for the Provision of Education in Rural Australia Inc, the minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Rural families are often concerned about educational opportunities for their children.

Yet he is quite happy to rip away at the programs that aim to provide these opportunities. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), recently allocated three-quarters of a million dollars to student unions in Victorian universities so that they can print articles about shoplifting.
