Yet he is not prepared to fund education so that all Australian children are guaranteed access to education. Was the money that was used to fund articles encouraging students to shoplift torn away from the rural hostels program?

PARA.TAB: The issue of allocation of resources should be of concern to many in the school sector. It was recently made clear by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that the government, in the unfortunate event that it is re-elected, intends to further centralise the funding of schools. In one of his many notorious forays into the portfolio responsibilities of Minister Free, Minister Crean stated on July 18 this year:

SPEECH.PARA: It makes me wonder if untying grants is the right way to go.

Simply, this is code for increasing the power of Canberra over Australian education. If the government is allowed to go along this path it will destroy the flexibility that schools and states currently enjoy in funding allocation. It will mean that decisions will be made by Canberra bureaucrats, as opposed to those within the school community who are directly affected by the decision.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that, for all his comments about state education, the opposition leader in Victoria is apparently very keen to ensure that schools at the grassroots level maintain the flexibility that they have at the moment. One can only assume that he would be vehemently opposed to the move that Minister Crean seems hell-bent on implementing. In short, this approach will mean that schools will be Canberra managed.

Like it or not, we live in a federation where education is the primary responsibility of the states. The government has now signalled its intention to stop untied grants without providing any reasonable rationale for doing so. I will be interested to hear the views of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training on this issue. Was his senior minister expressing his own opinion, the government's opinion, or Minister Free's opinion? Whose opinion was Minister Crean expressing when, for example, he accused the Victorian government of siphoning federal education funding into `casinos and racetracks'? This totally unsubstantiated comment was a gross abuse of ministerial responsibility, and by his silence the minister for schools is equally implicated in this outlandish claim.

What we are seeing in relation to the federal government's position vis-a-vis funding for the states is utter confusion caused by too many people interfering in areas for which they are not directly responsible. Minister Crean has threatened to scrap $16 million in extra school funding next year if Victoria does not join national literacy and education outcomes programs. But this view is entirely inconsistent with the praise lavished on the Victorian government's literacy initiatives by the minister for schools in the House on 23 August when he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is delighted that a Liberal state government has seen the merits of what the Commonwealth has been trying to achieve in the field of literacy.
Minister Free went on to say:
I should add that I am happy the Victorian statement contains an emphasis on the reporting of outcomes.

If Minister Crean makes good in his threat to cut this funding, where does this leave Minister Free or, more importantly, the people of Victoria? And which state will be next on Minister Crean's political hit list?

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that Minister Crean constantly takes over the responsibilities of Minister Free. He gets into areas where he is not welcome and I am sure it is a cause of embarrassment for Minister Free, because he uses political opportunism to sink his boots into the states. If he has legitimate complaints about the states, fair enough. But when it is just political and when he is overriding the responsibility of his ministerial colleague, my view is that he should butt out of it and leave it to the person who has the responsibility.

Attention also needs to be drawn to the fact that the government no longer feels that gifted and talented children are worthy of federal funding. These children deserve support and recognition of their talents, and a commitment by the government to nurture these abilities. This government's failure to do this is a very telling reflection on it and how it sees Australia in the future. We will not be a clever country if we neglect students in this group. By abolishing funding to these students the government is in fact punishing them for accelerating and achieving to a very high standard.

Proper education policy has been railroaded by a Treasury and Finance edict which has being handed to the minister and with which he must comply. This legislation reveals just what the ALP intends to do in the unlikely event that it is returned to government. These cuts are just the first stage of the government's agenda to reduce funding for education. This is what was shown in the budget leaks, this is what is shown in this legislation, and this is what will be evident after the election if Labor is returned.

The government says it is proud of its record on schooling. Yet it has devoted a mere handful of pages in its Shaping the Nation document—better known as `Shafting the Nation'—to substantiating its so-called achievements in this area. As we debate what will possibly be the last bill of this parliament which allocates funding to schools, I believe that it is appropriate to look at some of what the government claims has been achieved through legislation such as this, and what the actual outcomes have been.

The government claims to have brought in `vocational education reforms which concentrate on matching industry needs'—that is a quote from `Shafting the Nation'. Yet many reports, such as the Karpin report, the CEDA report and the FitzGerald report, all reveal that vocational education and training is irrelevant to the needs of many businesses and industry. Training is not providing the links with these sectors that was promised in Working Nation. As a result, we are seeing appalling low levels of trainees and apprentices to the extent where, as a proportion of the labour force, the number of apprentices and trainees is now at its lowest point in a quarter of a century. The report by CEDA further reveals that Australia has one of the lowest rates of participation in secondary level vocational education in the OECD. This is not the sign of a successful vocational education training system, nor is it an achievement a government should be proud of.

In the area of retention rates, the government claims in `Shafting the Nation' that under Labor they have `improved dramatically'. The latest retention rate figures from the ABS show a retention rate of 74.6 per cent for 1994—

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The member for Ballarat keeps making reference to a report which he has given a misnomer. He has made his point. I think he now has an obligation to refer to the report by its correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did refer to the report as Shaping the Nation, and went on to say that it was—
—I am aware of what you went on to say. I think the point was made and that the report is entitled to be referred to by its correct title.

—The Shaping the Nation report—which, as Mr Deputy Speaker quite rightly indicates, I have referred to as `Shafting the Nation'—said that under Labor they had `improved dramatically'. The latest retention rate figures from the ABS show a retention rate of 74.6 per cent for 1994, which follows the downward pattern since the peak of 77.1 per cent in 1992. The government has been quick to distance itself from this decrease.In a press release of 30 January 1995, Minister Free wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Member for Ballarat criticises the Federal Government because retention rates were down in the past year. But it is the States which have the responsibility for running schools.

Thus, as retention rates decrease, the federal government becomes less keen to be associated with them. When they were up, to use an expression which I think is one that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) uses—I do not know whether it is one of his or he has borrowed it—the government was absolutely `rusted' onto retention rates. Indeed, the government was claiming all the credit for it. Shaping the Nation—`Shafting the Nation'—indeed speaks in glowing terms about the federal government's involvement. But, as soon as the WD40 comes on, it is rusted off and the numbers start dropping, all of a sudden it becomes the responsibility of the states. There is no longer any kudos, and the government is running away, not interested in it.

PARA.TAB: The government claims to have developed a national curriculum for the compulsory years of schooling, yet the two most populous states—Victoria and New South Wales—have all but abandoned the curriculum. Professor Eltis found that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are doubts about the quality, content rigour, interpretation and validity of the National Profiles, and to some extent the National Statements.
The Eltis report also described the national curriculum as:
. . . vague, inconsistent and arbitrary and oriented towards process rather than understanding.

The report concludes that the New South Wales Board of Studies should `no longer be required to incorporate the National Profiles directly into NSW syllabuses'.So stung by these criticisms was Minister Free that he went to the House on 20 September to state that:
. . . curriculum remains—as it always has—in the hands of the states.
This is yet another example of the government attempting to distance itself from yet another failure.

PARA.TAB: What is most surprising is that the document makes no mention of teachers. It would appear that, as far as the Labor government is concerned, teachers do not play an important part in Shaping the Nation. This failure is even more surprising when we see the outcome of a survey conducted by the Australian Teaching Council, where it was found that teachers often feel the community holds them in low regard and does not understand the nature of their work. If our teachers do not feel confident themselves, or do not feel confident they have the support of the community, how can we expect them to feel confident about the job they are doing?

The next election will be a very important one for the school community throughout Australia. This legislation shows the cuts Labor has in store and the way it is prepared to treat with neglect those who do not live in the capital cities and those who have talents which need to be nurtured. It also shows the highly centralised structure that the government wishes to impose on school funding if given a chance. This is clearly what the Labor Party offers schools post the next election.

This is not the way the coalition views education. A coalition government will provide support to states—rather than threatening or intimidating them—in their efforts to improve the quality of education. A coalition government will acknowledge that the desire for an education does not end with the city limits, and we will ensure improved access for isolated students. A coalition government will improve access not only for isolated children but also for other educationally disadvantaged children.

A coalition government will encourage greater diversity within the school system and widen opportunities for a parental choice in schooling, rather than centralising the system. The coalition's approach will be to listen to the community rather than dictate to it. Come election day, the choice will be very clear for all Australians. What this legislation has shown is that, after 12 1/2 years, Labor has been able to offer little in the area of education. As both ministers squabble over who has portfolio responsibility for what, many in the school sector have began to ignore them. Based on the government's record, as espoused in Shaping the Nation—or `Shafting the Nation—this should come as no surprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Ballarat runs the risk of defying the ruling of the chair.

—I am sorry, I thought you were asking me to clarify the report and then make a comment. I know there are other colleagues who are anxious to talk, including the member for Port Adelaide, but let there be no doubt about the campaign being run by this government in relation to education: it is a subliminal thing that is just tossed in here and tossed in there. The Prime Minister, the great promise breaker himself, has been running around this country saying that the coalition is going to slash Medicare and slash funding for education.

PARA.TAB: I ask everyone to go back and have a look at those budget leaks, before the last budget, and see what this government was going to do with education. There is absolutely no doubt, and this bill is a classic example of it, that this government is starting to nibble away at education and it will continue to do so. It is the government and not the coalition that intends not only to centralise the education system but also to reduce funding to education. As I said, in the very, very unlikely event that the government is re-elected, this is what will happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposals in this bill provide further evidence of the very big difference between Labor and the coalition on education policy and political philosophy generally. I should point out to the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), whom I like—he is a good fellow—that the Commonwealth government and the governments of Queensland and New South Wales are the only three governments in this nation to have expanded expenditure on education.

PARA.TAB: The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 contains two very important provisions. Firstly, it provides for an extension of the early literacy program. This program fosters literacy development for children in the early years of schooling—it is a crucial program—with a special emphasis on children with the disadvantage of low socioeconomic circumstances. The member for Ballarat mentioned the national literacy survey, which is a very important one, but he failed to mention that the state of Victoria will not cooperate. In fact the state of New South Wales, until Premier Carr was elected, also refused to cooperate. That has now of course changed. Other states, such as South Australia and Western Australia, have agreed to provide information to the federal government.

Secondly, this bill makes provision to assist students with disabilities to make the transition to mainstream school education or to pursue further training and employment. These two provisions are designed to enhance opportunities for students who might otherwise be denied fair access and equal opportunity. This is affirmative action as it should be, focusing on the young, the poor and the disabled, regardless of gender, race, ethnicity or religion. The bill illustrates important philosophical differences between Labor and the conservatives. For example, Labor believes government has a role to play in bringing about equality of opportunity. The conservatives believe government has no such role to play. The Kennett, Brown and Court Liberal governments in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia are perfect examples of the non-role conservative governments wish to play.

This conservative view of a limited role for government has as its underlying assumption the notion that disadvantage is the fault of those who are disadvantaged and that therefore disadvantage is something which the individual must overcome, with the help, perhaps, of charities. But a role for government in bringing about equality of access and opportunity is not something the conservative mind will concede. One of the reasons why the conservatives have been out of office for so long is that the conservative view is not consistent with the Australian idea of a fair go for all. However, it does appear that the conservatives have woken up to the fact that Australians reject their dog eat dog vision of the future for this country. Remember Fightback? What is their response?

TALK.START.PARA: —All the lies about it.

—We will get onto lies in a minute. They simply refuse to tell the electorate what their policies are. The honourable member for Ballarat in his 30 minutes did not mention one policy. Not one. Just Like Mr Kennett, Mr Court and Mr Brown before him, the Federal Liberal leader, Mr Howard, refuses to tell the Australian people what his party would do should they win government.

PARA.TAB: The irony in all of this is that, while it is an act of secretiveness, an attempt to deceive, it is also very revealing. Consider this. If you have policies of which you are proud, which you are prepared to stand up for and to be judged on—education policies or whatever—what reason could there be for withholding them from the electorate? Of course, there is only one reason and it has two parts. Firstly, they know their policies will not stand up to scrutiny. Secondly, they know that they will be rejected.

On these counts, they are probably correct. Once freed of the rhetoric and properly analysed, the electorate will reject their policies. It is as simple as that. They will reject them because one of the things that the Australian people insist on is fairness and equality of opportunity—a fair go for everybody. These are the very characteristics which Liberal policies will not contain. As a rule, their policies are demonstration of a mean-spiritedness, and are hardest on those who most need assistance—the young, the poor, the disabled.

For proof of this, look at the performance of any of the Liberal state governments: there are common threads running through them all. One common thread is that they have been prepared deliberately to deceive the electorate in order to get elected. All of them refused to release their policies in time for adequate public scrutiny in the lead-up to the polls at which they were elected. Others told outright untruths. For example, the South Australian Premier, Mr Brown, promised more money for education. The fact is that, by l996, he will have chopped $100 million off the education budget. I think Mr Kennett has chopped $400 million off the education budget. Premier Brown in South Australia has removed more than 1,600 teachers and support staff from the schools. There can be no contest on this. Mr Brown and his then shadow minister, Mr Lucas, told untruths to the South Australian public in order to get elected. The proof is in the pudding.

Another common thread is the one that runs through the personal characteristics of Liberal leaders. It is that they display an antagonism, a resentment, towards ordinary working people. Why this is so would be a very interesting thesis for a psychology doctorate.

Phillip Adams, writing in the Weekend Australian, put the problems of the Liberal leadership down to poor potty training. He describes Mr Howard as not merely conservative, but reactionary. He says that Howard is a cloud of pessimism, an albatross around the electorate's neck, a harbinger of doom, who seems weighed down with bitterness and self-pity. Phillip Adams says that, when he thinks of Mr Howard, the initials `PM' mean `post-mortem' rather than `Prime Minister'. He says that the man was born to be a mortician, if not a corpse. What seethes in Howard, he writes, is resentment.

This resentment, this bitterness and antagonism towards the working people of this country, is a trait Mr Howard shares with the Liberal state premiers. It would not be harmful except for the fact that their policies reflect this peculiar bitterness and resentment. For example, the Court government is enacting industrial relations legislation which appears to be specifically designed to cause hardship and industrial disruption. Of course, the teachers in Western Australia are very angry at the Court government.

Administrators who wish to achieve results in the public service for the common good of all parties, and for the country generally, would not take such a confrontationist course of action. Labor governments have followed sensible, cooperative industrial relations policies, which have seen great improvement in productivity and flexibility while, at the same time, markedly reducing the incidence of time and money wasting disputes.

That is sensible administration. Despite it being sensible, the productive way, Liberal leaders refuse to take that path. They appear to want to credential themselves with achieving industrial unrest and they do not seem to care who it involves, whether it is our schools or our teachers. It does not matter. It is an attack on ordinary working men and women. It is very odd behaviour. It is not only in industrial relations. The Court government's approach to Mabo and its refusal to correct the disgraceful electoral gerrymander in that state also reveal its contempt for matters of justice and for the very tenets of our democracy.

The other Liberal governments have similar report cards. They have all striven to stifle equality of opportunity, to stir up workplace confrontation, to deny democratic rights and to silence opponents by threats, untruths and any other means possible. The South Australian Premier, Mr Brown, fits the mould perfectly. He too appears driven by resentment and a preparedness to tell untruths.

This is his report card. He told untruths to the electorate about expanding education funding. He attempted to deceive the electorate and the parliament over the Catch Tim and Moriki affairs regarding secret donations to the Liberal Party. Questions remain unanswered regarding the special grants given to Gerard Industries Pty Ltd and what links these grants might have had with the secret donations scandal. Questions also remain unanswered about the reasons for the removal of the TAB chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're drawing the bow a bit long there, aren't you?

—Knowledge comes out of the head, not the mouth. The Auditor-General has severely criticised the Brown government for the secrecy surrounding the deals it is making with private enterprises in the current fire sale of South Australian assets and—I hope you are listening to this—most damaging to Mr Brown's personal credibility is—
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. We are talking about government donations. I fail to see any relevance whatsoever to the bill before us.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—As long as the honourable member talks about education, it will be condoned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an expose. I make the point—
—What's the point?

—The point is that the most vulnerable group in this country is children who are compulsorily at school. Those children do not have a union. We are the people they rely on. They rely on our integrity to provide for them and their future. The credibility and the stature of political leaders in this country and in the states is very critical; in fact it is the critical thing for young children. What happened in South Australia—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—They do not like me telling the truth.

—I think I have the call, Mr Deputy Speaker. I heard the ruling you just gave, but the bill we have here is on very specific areas. It has to do with funding related to rural hostels, gifted children and gender equity. They are education issues. I think it is drawing a pretty long bow to talk about political party funding or donations or what schoolchildren might think as they watch the television in the context of a bill that deals with those very specific things.
—The latitude given to the honourable member for Ballarat seemed to me to be fairly wide ranging and I am prepared to continue that latitude as long as the matter of education is being dealt with.
—Was the member for Ballarat referring to political party funding or comments made by other parties and—
—Medicare, industrial relations.
—I do ask members to stick to the matter of education because the legislation is fairly limited. However, I am prepared to tolerate debate to the extent of dealing with education.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I repeat, in the lead-up to the 1993 election in South Australia the Liberals promised that spending on education would increase. That is what they promised. By 1996 they will have cut $100 million out of the budget. It is important to know what people in South Australia and in other areas think of this government.

PARA.TAB: In a finding in the court, Justice Olsen cast severe doubts on the credibility of the Premier's testimony as a witness in the court. He said that he unhesitatingly preferred the evidence given by Mr Blaikie, the CEO of the health department, to that given by Premier Brown. Justice Olsen said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am also of the impression that some aspects of his—
that is, Premier Brown's—
evidence may have been influenced by a degree of ex post facto reasoning.

The obvious interpretation of that is that Mr Brown has been caught telling untruths in court. That is his behavioural report card. This is the person who is going to be responsible for our young people.

PARA.TAB: The story is no better on policy. The promise was made during the 1993 election in South Australia that they would expand expenditure on education. That was an untruth. The facts prove it was an untruth. It was part of a deliberate strategy to gain office at any cost—in particular, at the cost of the truth. It reveals their contempt for the electorate.

The facts are these: the education budget has already been cut by $40 million, with another $60 million to come; class sizes have been increased; and, at the latest count, more than 1,600 teachers and support staff have gone. The latest decision, to cut the equivalent of 250 full-time school service officers, will hit the schools in the lower socioeconomic areas hardest. This has been a pattern of the Brown government's administration—and not only in education. School service officers are commonly part-time, low income positions, but they do provide a very important service to students in a range of areas and help encourage students complete their schooling. The cuts apply to the number of staff, not to the work they are expected to perform. This will mean more stress for the remaining support staff and for teachers. In the end, it is the children's education which will suffer.

One notorious Liberal member in South Australia, Mr Joe Rossi, the member for Lee, suggested to his community—also my community—that parents could quite easily take the place of school officers at no cost whatsoever. Good one, Joe! That was almost as good as his suggestion to sterilise single mothers and blame the employees at the Garibaldi factory for the tragic poisoning situation that occurred there.

The education cuts are another demonstration of the different priorities between the Liberal and Labor parties. South Australia has lost the position it gained under Labor of being internationally recognised as a leader in education. It is now going backwards. Our retention rates, once the best in the country at 93 per cent, have now crashed to 76 per cent. If you are going to take $100 million out of the money that is going to be spent on schools, of course it is going to have some deleterious effects.

Students who complete year 12 have a marked advantage in developing to their full potential through further full-time education or employment based development. It should be a matter of grave concern to a minister of education that one in four of our students disappears from the system. Four thousand have disappeared so far this year in South Australia. But how does the minister, Mr Lucas, respond to this? Is he concerned about what is happening to the students who are disappearing from the education system? Is he taking any action to reverse the decline? Is he doing something about TAFE? The answer is that he is not. His only response is simply to gloat about the savings that the decline in retention rates brings. It is a disgraceful response from an education minister, but it is very consistent with the conservative philosophy that apportions blame to those who suffer disadvantage and denies a role for government in providing assistance.

The member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) said recently, very revealingly, that there was no role for government in picking up the pieces of a family breakup. Some commentators have dismissed this as an aberration. But the point is that it is not an aberration; it is mainstream Liberal thinking on the role of government. The proof of that is in the pudding of the policies they enact when in government. It also demonstrates the failure of the Liberal government to recognise trends in the labour market and to response appropriately to them.

Full-time jobs for youths aged 15 to 19 have been declining for the last couple of decades as the economy modernises and gains an international focus. The role for government in these changing times is to assist students to gain the qualifications they need to enter the work force, but the Liberals see no role for government here. Their response is simply to gloat about the savings made when people fall through the system and lose opportunity, and in the end that will be more costly, both in personal terms and in terms of the national economy. It is our greatest asset. That is a cliche, I know, that is used far too often, but it is true.

It is not only the school education system. For the people who are being removed from the school system, what the government is doing in TAFE in South Australia is nothing short of a tragedy. Labor had made TAFE industry-driven, but still responsive to the needs of the whole community, and with the strongest commitment to access and equity, to equal opportunity. With the federal government, the previous state Labor government funded training places for thousands more young people to enable TAFE to respond even better to the training requirements of industry. All that is now sadly in jeopardy in South Australia. It is the only state in the Commonwealth yet to meet the criteria for Commonwealth growth funds to flow. In a typically short-sighted move the Brown government has cut funding to TAFE by $5 million in dollar terms—but by much more in real terms, of course. Our TAFE system's institutions are being bled dry and it is the provision of a skilled work force that is being compromised.

This bill, in providing for early literacy programs, especially for those disadvantaged by low socioeconomic circumstances, and in providing for improved access and equity for people with disabilities, demonstrates as well as any bill can the difference between the priorities of the government and the conservative opposition. The Liberals do not have any commitment to the principles of equal access and equal opportunity and they fail to grasp the critical link between a strong education and training system and the building of a modern efficient economy.

In contrast, the federal Labor government's record is proven. Labor has created a decade of expansion of education opportunity at all levels. It has increased opportunity for individuals. It has lifted our economic performance. And it has provided the skills and flexibility needed in our emerging and modern economy. When the opposition was last in government, seven out of 10 young Australians left the education system without completing high school. Most of those people are in the labour market today—many of them unemployed due to that criminal neglect. Now, the opposition's colleagues in state governments are repeating the same policies. They are quashing opportunity, rather than enhancing opportunity.

Should the opposition win government at the next federal poll, they would make the same savage cuts their counterparts in the states have made. They would contract opportunity, rather than expand it. They would turn students out of the education and training system, rather than fund their futures. I believe the people of South Australia, the people in my electorate of Port Adelaide, and all Australians deserve much better, and I commend this bill to the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 today, I will refer to some very detailed work that has been done by groups throughout Australia and I will rely upon some of that work in my remarks. I want to dwell on one particular aspect of this bill—the cessation of the $1.1 million rural hostels program. While this would appear to be a paltry sum, the number of people living outside of the major towns and cities in Australia that have secondary school education available to them is probably in excess of half a million.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), made a great issue of social justice and spoke about social injustice. There can be no greater social injustice than the deprivation of a secondary school education. It is an injustice to deprive a person of an ability to gain a job. Almost 80 per cent of jobs in society today have secondary education as a prerequisite. If you have not got it, 80 per cent of the jobs in society today are not available to you. Your ability to go into business for yourself is seriously curtailed by a lack of a secondary education. In fact, it could be said that without a secondary education you are an economic pariah and—I venture to suggest—possibly a social pariah as well.

If you look at the seven major electorates in Australia—Northern Territory, Kalgoorlie, South Australia, which is almost one electorate, my own electorate of Kennedy as well as Leichhardt and Maranoa in Queensland, and Parkes in New South Wales—they take up 82 per cent of the surface area of Australia. And if I shave off the edges of my own electorate and Leichhardt—the coastal belt that is about 40 kilometres wide—those electorates contain 3 1/2 per cent of the Australian population. But let us just use a rough figure of half a million people living in those electorates, or that 82 per cent of the surface area of Australia.

While there are towns that are big enough to have secondary school education, such as Mount Isa and Longreach, to name two in my own electorate, there is a very significant proportion of those people—some 20,000 or 30,000 in the electorate of Kennedy—who have no access to secondary school education whatsoever. If there are 10 situations like that throughout Australia—and it is a lot worse in some of the other electorates, I might say, than in my own—there are, on that basis, some 200,000 Australians who are being deprived of a secondary education. That used not to be the situation, and I think there is a modicum of hypocrisy with people who come into this house and talk about social justice. There is social justice for those people living in big towns and cities but, for those people living in small towns, there is no social justice whatsoever. They have no ability to secure for themselves a secondary school education.

The situation has changed dramatically since 1986 in Queensland. If you turn the clock back, the cost of going away to a boarding school was about $6,600—if my memory serves me correctly—and the entire cost of going away was picked up by the state and federal governments. The incoming socialist state government in Queensland effectively removed what was called the remote area scholarship, which was a straight $2,000 in the hand, on top of the other assistance that was and still is available. In the meantime, of course, as far as schools are concerned, the cost of sending a child away to school has risen from about $6,500 a year to about $8,500 a year. I am not talking here about elitist GPS schools; I am talking about church schools in North Queensland that were built for the specific purpose of providing a secondary school education to kids who would otherwise not have had such an education.

When the remote area scholarship was removed, the federal government made a token effort to overcome the problem by instituting a system that we are removing here today: the system of country hostels. They said, `At least you can go to Mount Isa or to Longreach, because there is a hostel there and you can get your secondary school education there, and that will be cheaper than the church-run boarding schools.' But, quite frankly, it has not worked out to be as cheap as the church-run boarding schools. It has possibly worked out to be more expensive, but there is one great advantage: the kids can be brought home at weekends. For people close in, that was a very significant advantage of the hostels, because the kids could go home of a weekend, and the parents did not have to pay for having the child looked after of a weekend.

Today, the modicum of effort that was made to overcome this terribly oppressive and tyrannical injustice is being removed. I simply do not know why there would be, in a period of great trauma for rural Australia, such a nasty, vicious attempt to remove what little access rural people had to secondary school education. Let me say to those people who are doing this today that England did the same thing to Ireland, which was for some 200 years deprived of an education. It was almost impossible to get an education if you were Irish. Of course, 200 years later, England is still harvesting the seeds of hatred that it sowed during that period of time. Today, those same seeds of hatred are being sown in country Australia—seeds that will be carried by people for the rest of their days and by future generations of people who do not live in the big cities of Australia.

Recently, I submitted to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters a submission concerning, effectively, the situation in country areas in Australia. Under the heading, `Tyranny of the majority', I referred to some remarks which are very pertinent to the debate today, words written by Alexis de Tocqueville in 1835, in De la Democratie en Amerique. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Democracy should not be allowed to become a mechanism by which the majority can oppress the minority. Safe guards to protect basic rights—
I venture to submit that there is no more basic right than a secondary education—
and freedoms need to be built into the system. Otherwise democracy could become just another instrument of tyranny.
Under the heading `No taxation without representation', I stated that in 1775, in A Summary View of the Rights of America, Thomas Jefferson wrote:

The concept of a tax being arbitrarily imposed upon a people without those being taxed having any real say in the levying and expenditure of such moneys is a concept repugnant to all people who believe in Freedom.

In Julia Creek and Richmond, we are paying the same taxes as people pay in Brisbane but we have no right or access to a secondary school education—none! And I am not even talking about a tertiary education: this is simply secondary education. In my submission, under the heading `Government for the good of all, not just the majority', I also quoted Encyclopaedia Britannica on Edmund Burke. It says:
Burke supported . . . the widening of political participation . . . provided there was restraint of aggressive partiality . . . Burke rejected any doctrine of mere rule of numbers.

Burke was saying exactly the same thing as Alexis de Tocqueville and Thomas Jefferson. These people, who had sat down and thought about the way that the system worked, could clearly foresee the terrible oppression which was going to be meted out to minority groups in society today. This injustice is able to happen today because, in the Labor Party room, there are only two or three spokesmen for outback Australia. In the Coalition Party room, there are only two or three spokesmen for outback Australia. We have a policy in Australia of having the same number of people in every electorate. What in the cities is called `one vote, one value' is in country areas called `one vote, no value'.

PARA.TAB: In the United States of America, a congressman from California District 37 has 979,966 electors. A congressman from Montana, in Marlanee congressional district—or electorate, as we would call it—has 381,849 electors. There is a variation of 250 per cent in electoral enrolments for the American Congress. The United States Senate is, of course, also a legislature—entirely different from our Senate. In that particular legislature, the state of California has 30 million people and is represented by two senators, while the nearby state of Arizona has 400,000 people and also has two senators. There is a 10,000 per cent difference in their Senate.

In the Canadian House of Representatives, Missiissauga West has 148,853 electors and Nunatsiaq has 14,386 electors, a difference of 1,000 per cent. This is the same mechanism that is enabling our parliament to remove the right to secondary education from our people. In Great Britain, Westbury has 87,537 electors and Western Isles has 22,785 electors, a 400 per cent discrepancy. To summarise, the United States Congress has a 250 per cent variation, the United States Senate has a 10,000 per cent variation, Canada has a 1,000 per cent variation, Great Britain has a 400 per cent variation and Australia has a two per cent variation. The most unpopulated continent on the entire planet has a two per cent variation. That is how and why our children can be deprived of a secondary education.

There is worse still than that—far worse. The seven House of Representatives seats that are largest in area are, not in any order, Parkes, Kennedy, Maranoa, Leichhardt, Kalgoorlie, Grey and the Northern Territory. The seven House of Representative seats that are largest in population are, in order, the Northern Territory and Kalgoorlie, which appear in the first group; Sydney, which does not appear there; Leichhardt, which appears in the first group; Melbourne, which does not appear there; Kennedy, which appears in the first group; and Grayndler. Of the seven seats largest in area in Australia, four of them also have the largest population.

The viciousness of the system that has been imposed upon us says that, if you are dying out there, you have to have a hell of a lot more people in your electorate than if you are growing. We are dying because we have not even got any secondary education that we can provide for our kids. People are running away at a hundred miles an hour. Therefore, because we are dying, we have to have less representation than people in the cities have. I have 85,000 electors in my electorate, but most of the people sitting opposite have 72,000 in theirs. Some of them are down in the 60,000 range.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over 83,000. Don't tell porkies.

—There are exceptions and, most certainly, two of the exceptions are Kalgoorlie and the Northern Territory. But let me move on. I put my itineraries for the last month in that submission and they show that 43 hours a week was spent on travel. Someone was stupid enough to say, `Why don't you travel in an aeroplane?' I said, `I was waiting for that question.' Only one of those trips in the last four weeks was done in a motor car and the rest were done in an aeroplane. To get anywhere in the electorate that I represent, even in a light aircraft, means travelling three or four hours. It is worse still for the member of Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I cannot help but mention, in the context of this deprivation, the situation of people out there. The average Australian worker earns $644 a week and the taxation rate in Australia is 29 per cent, which is $215. When we take that off the $644 it leaves him with $429.

PARA.TAB: The cost of living in the mid-west region of Queensland—which is my electorate—and the central west is 24 per cent higher than it is in Brisbane. It would be a lot worse in the Northern Territory, in the electorate of Kalgoorlie and in the north of South Australia. When we include that 24 per cent, or $132, that leaves him with $297 as his income. If he is married with one child, he is $50 a week below the poverty line. The average Australian living out there in that other Australia, which is 82 per cent of the surface area of the continent, lives $50 below the poverty line.

I have been very general in my remarks about the issue of deprivation but I now want to be very specific about it. I rang all of the big boarding schools in Charter Towers to ask about their fees. These are the schools that service northern Australia. They are all church schools and they are run very cheaply. They are not GPS schools; the figures for the GPS boarding schools in Brisbane would be twice these figures. For the Catholic schools there, the figure is $7,540. The Anglican school fees are $8,280 and the Uniting Church affiliated school fees are also $8,280. The fees for the Cathedral School, an Anglican school in Townsville, are $8,350.

The average for those schools is $8,160, and I must emphasise that they are in the northern half of the state. If children have to go to school in the southern half of the state, and there are only GPS schools, elitist schools, the fees are almost twice what I am quoting here. I would advise people in the southern half of the state to go to school in the northern half of the state. On top of the school fees, and I now refer to an article in Tuesday's Sydney Morning Herald, there are additional costs to a total of $4,350. There are things in that list that parents of kids going to a state school in Sydney would like their children to have such as music tuition and private tuition, and they would probably like to be able to spend huge amounts of money on odds and ends.

I have deducted all of those things and I have simply kept in the figures from the Sydney Morning Herald, which are taken from a study by the Australian Scholarships Group. The additional costs are listed as: stationery, $283 a year; text books, $269 a year; art and craft materials, $121 a year; clothing for boys, $378 a year, which I think is a bit high but those are the official figures of the study; sport and sporting equipment, $232; and outings and trips, $162. That comes to $1,485. For children going away to boarding school, there is another $500 on top of that. I think that is a fairly moderate figure for travel to and from school for the four terms of the year. With that $500 there that is $1,900 on top of the $8,000 for fees. So we have a figure close to $10,000, and for that you will get the princely sum from the state and federal governments of $4,600. In some enormously extenuating circumstances, it might be possible to get $5,000. I do not know of anyone who is getting $5,000. I think $4,600 is a fairly generous figure, as far as assistance people can get from the commonwealth and state governments, and that is the maximum.

For each child there is a shortfall of $5,000 a year and this is for people who are lucky if they are earning an average weekly wage. Of course, rural workers are some of the most lowly paid people in society today. Probably the only people worse off are the farmers themselves, whose incomes are even lower. However, these people have to find, if they have got two kids, $10,000 a year, and when they are already $50 a week below the poverty line that would be a good trick for them.

So it comes as no surprise that in remote areas—and all of the Northern Territory is a remote area with the exception of Darwin; Alice Springs and all of my electorate, except for the coast, are remote areas—55 per cent of kids complete grade 12, whereas in urban communities 73 per cent complete grade 12. Quite frankly, that 55 per cent is a 1991 figure and I guarantee that it will be a lot worse than that now.

We do have a lot of people of Aboriginal descent who have special funding available to them, so they can at least get away to school. That 55 per cent would be accounted for to a very large degree by those who are of Aboriginal descent. Once I used to say that there would be some rich people too in that figure but there would be very few of those now. That figure also includes people who have contracts with their mining companies to provide education. Clearly, 50 per cent fewer people from rural Australia will complete grade 12 than in an urban situation.

I must also mention the tertiary level in remote areas. A map of Australia showing remote areas shows that that is almost the entire surface area of the continent. A higher education series update of 3 November 1992 reported that the participation rate in higher education among people from remote areas was less than half the participation rate of people from urban areas. Let me be more specific: 27.7 per cent of people from urban areas participate in tertiary education as against about 14 per cent in rural areas. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to rise to support the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. The bill amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act of 1992 and gives effect to several government initiatives announced in 1995-96 budget. It is part of this government's ongoing commitment to providing young Australians with a quality education that will expand their economic and social opportunities.

PARA.TAB: Labor governments in power have always attached a high priority to the funding of education in Australia. If we go back in recent history, we can note the enormous achievements of the Whitlam government in the funding of higher education and, of course, secondary and primary education in Australia. That very proud tradition has been carried on by the Hawke and Keating governments, and that commitment is reflected in the funds that are being allocated by this bill today.

The Labor Party has always viewed education as a key to unlocking the potential of the people of this nation. Labor in government has always treated education as an investment, not simply as a cost to the Commonwealth budget. In running a modern society and economy, the government is cognisant of the fact that education plays a key role in preparing its citizens to meet the economic challenges that face them today.

We have seen enormous changes take place in the Australian economy over the past decade. Significant changes in global markets and the introduction of new technologies have created a demand for Australians to be very flexible and adaptive in their workplaces. At the core of preparing for the challenges of the new industrial workplace is education. If we are to ensure that all Australians have the opportunity to share the wealth of the nation, and if we are to achieve social justice within this society, then we must pour resources at the Commonwealth level into education.

As far as the elements of this bill are concerned, there are two very important provisions that relate to the achievement of the government's social justice objectives. The first is the extension of the early literacy program into 1996. The government has allocated some $8.9 million in 1996 to this program, which is directed at the detection of early literacy problems in students.

I do not think we ought to walk away from the sad reality that many Australians are unable to read. That problem is not confined to the younger people in our population; it is a widespread problem across all ages. Problems with illiteracy come from a multitude of causes: it may be a physical limitation of the individual concerned; it may well be the failure of schools to really complete the educational task, or it might be due to social factors such as poverty or the fact that the person has migrated to Australia and does not have a very good command of the language.

The costs to society of illiteracy are enormous. The cost to the individuals can be appreciated by the fact that they are not empowered in a personal sense and have difficulty functioning in society. As far as the economy is concerned, modern industry relies on a work force that is literate, that not only possesses the ability to read but also understands the need for change and can appreciate, to some degree, the environment in which the enterprise is operating at the domestic and international level. Of course, those problems are compounded in enterprises where workers do not have base standards of literacy.

I am very pleased that the government has, through this program, sought to address the problems of literacy in our schools. Prevention is better than cure and, if we can put resources into schools and into these institutions at the early stages of the development of individuals to ensure that they are able to read and they are able to write, then it certainly overcomes problems later on. It is less costly in the long term.

Another important provision of this bill is the assistance that it provides to non-government schools to assist students with disabilities. The government is providing some $3.2 million in 1996 to a program which is designed to assist students with disabilities with that transition to mainstream education, employment or further training. I guess that at this point we ought to reflect on the roles that governments play in our society. It is very clear that the marketplace, left to itself in the educational area, will not ensure a clear flow of resources to people with disabilities, or provide them with the opportunities once they leave school to participate in the economic life of the nation. There is extra special tuition required, and extra resources have been made available through this program to assist those people with their integration into further education and training or into the work force.
In addition, this bill adjusts the capital and recurrent grants for 1995 and 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you assist them if you can't assist country kids?

—I will take up some of the issues that the honourable member has raised. I have some particular things to say about the conservative state governments in this country, and their attitude to education. But just let me reiterate: this bill adjusts capital and recurrent grants for 1995 and 1996 for movements in various indexes used for the disbursement of funds. Additional amounts in 1995 for capital expenditures will be $7 million and for recurrent expenditures, $55 million; in 1996, it will be $7 million for capital expenditures and $56 million for recurrent expenditures.

PARA.TAB: This government has a demonstrated commitment, not a fabricated commitment, to education at all levels of education in Australia. For example, at the higher education level the federal government commits some $1.5 billion to the education of young and older Australians. In my electorate, we have one of the best universities in the nation, Deakin University, which was recently acknowledged by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) in the quality awards that were given. It is a major employer in Geelong; it provides quality programs, especially in the area of distance education. It has been an important climb up the quality ladder for Deakin University and I pay tribute in this debate to the staff and, indeed, the students that make up this very important educational institution not only in Geelong but in Australia.

As far as vocational education and training is concerned, the federal government outlays some $768 million in this particular area. In Geelong we have a very important technical and further education institution—the Gordon Technical College. Recently, the federal government tipped in around $30 million to the Gordon Technical College to build the manufacturing industry training centre, which will service manufacturing industry in the Geelong region, and also to refurbish the heritage buildings at the Gordon. This will certainly make it a more attractive institution to students, especially those from overseas who are coming to the Gordon to study.

As far as primary and secondary schools are concerned, this federal government has a demonstrated commitment to the extent of $3.14 billion in 1995, and that will increase to $3.18 billion in 1996. Primary and secondary schools in my electorate have been the beneficiaries of this very strong commitment of the federal Labor Party to education in Victoria, and particularly in Geelong.

For example, over the period 1984 to 1993, some $19.6 million has been allocated by the federal government to primary and secondary schools in the electorate. In 1995 the Newcomb Primary School received $126,000 for major maintenance; Nelson Park Primary School received $120,000; and Lara Primary School received $161,000 for the construction of physical education and music facilities and a refurbished canteen. The Lara Lake Primary School received $158,000 for additional classrooms; Geelong High School received $396,000 for external and internal maintenance to buildings; and Norlane High School received $185,000 to upgrade the science, graphic communications and technology facilities.

If we go back through the grants in 1994, St Josephs College received over $1 million from the federal government. Sacred Heart College received some $2 million in recurrent funding; Clonard College received $695,000; and the Holy Family Primary School received $755,000 for the refurbishment and reconstruction of the library and administration areas. Christ the King Primary School received $384,000 in recurrent grants—and so the list goes on. That is a sign of real commitment by a Labor government that has always had education and the funding of education as a top priority for—

TALK.START.PARA: —The city kids.

—No, it is not only for city kids. The member opposite interjects and I want to take him down to Victoria where a conservative state government, a Liberal-National party coalition state government, has literally ripped the insides out of the educational assets of the state. I heard the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) speak in this place about the fact that the Commonwealth government wants to know about retention rates only when they increase.

PARA.TAB: We all know what the legacy of a conservative government in Victoria was when the Cain government came to power in 1982 and the Hawke government came to power in 1983. The retention rates in our secondary schools were under 50 per cent. That was a disgraceful legacy to leave for Labor governments to fix up. That was the legacy of a conservative government in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Labor Government in Queensland we are the lowest in Australia.
—And what did Labor governments at the state and federal level do about that situation? We rectified it. We poured enormous resources into our state schools.
—I just tell you Queensland—
—We poured enormous resources federally into our schools, and we lifted the retention rates to around 90 per cent. That is the legacy of Labor governments at the state and federal level.
—No, in Queensland they've gone down. They're lower than your—
—And while the state Liberal government in Victoria—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —While the state Liberal government in Victoria, with the compliance of the National Party, closes schools in rural Victoria, and reduces funding to schools in rural Victoria—
—What about Queensland? You said Labor governments—
—The Labor government at the federal level has had to step in and ensure that funding is retained for educational purposes in our state.
—If Victoria is bad, Queensland is—
—The only legacy of the tories—

—Order! The member for Corio will remain quiet for a moment and resume his seat. The member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) is overdoing it in interjections. It is nice to have a little bit of repartee, but the member for Kennedy is grossly overdoing it. I call on the member for Corio.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I can appreciate the sensitivity of the honourable member, because he does not like to hear how the National Party has got in bed with the Liberal Party and ripped the insides out of rural education in the state of Victoria. He can waffle on all he likes about Queensland, but I am telling you the experience of Victoria.
—Hear, hear!

—The honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) is a person with a longstanding interest in education in Victoria and he does appreciate the points that I am making in this debate today. The honourable member opposite is a member of the National Party, which has got into bed with the Liberal Party in my state. The National Party has gone along with the ripping of the insides out of the educational fabric of the state.

PARA.TAB: Let me just make a few points about the achievements of the coalition state government in Victoria. We have had widespread closures of schools in rural areas. We have had massive reductions in staffing. We have a crisis in morale among our teachers in Victoria. They are suffering increased teaching loads. We have just seen a massive decline in the retention rates in Victorian schools and, above all, we have seen the Kennett government reduce funds for special education.

While the Victorian Premier swans about the state lining the pockets of his Liberal mates who own the casino in Melbourne, while he flits about, pouring enormous resources into the grand prix and feathering the pockets of his mates, Victorian schools go without. Victorian school children go without. That is the quality of the government that we have at the state level in Victoria. In Geelong, a city that had excellent educational infrastructure assets—and still has—let me say what the Kennett government has done. It flogged off the Institute of Educational Administration, which would have provided a national focus on the city, as far as education is concerned. They have closed schools in the region. They have reduced staff numbers in schools and they have cut special education to pieces.

This is the legacy of tory governments. We had them in Victoria before 1982 and the legacy that they left us to clean up in the state was a legacy of low retention rates, public schools that were poorly maintained, and a teaching profession that was not acknowledged for the contribution that it makes to the welfare of our students. I would like to comment on that teaching profession. Teachers today are called on not only to be teachers. They are called on to be administrators, mediators between students and their families, counsellors to students, and innovators within the school and the larger industrial environment. These are the qualities that are required of the modern-day teacher. But we know that the coalition parties do not hold the teaching profession in very high esteem. We do, on this side of the House, because we appreciate the enormous contribution that teachers make to the life of their communities, certainly to their students, and to the schools in which they teach.

I would like to pay a dedication here to a young man in Geelong. He is one of the top teachers in Victoria and has recently been nominated for an award. This is a young man by the name of Chris Lowrey. He has dedicated his life to the teaching of young people in the Geelong area and he is finally being acknowledged for that contribution.

We need to understand that our schools are different institutions. We must give our students within them the freedom to fail as well as the freedom to succeed. I think this is a point that is not understood by members opposite and other members of the community. Schools are indeed different institutions. They are not to be run strictly along business lines. It is not the function of teachers to go out and flog the school to seek sponsorship, which is what is happening in Victoria. They have an important responsibility to develop a sense of community, both within the confines of the school grounds and in the larger society in which they operate.

The society's demands on schools are enormous. I pay tribute to those in the teaching profession who must bear the onerous responsibilities that they do in schools today. I pay particular tribute to Labor governments in power that have had the will and the commitment to devote enormous resources to the advancement of Australian schools and Australian schoolchildren.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 with some sadness because, having listened to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), talk about the wonderful things that Labor governments have done in the states where they have held office, I am conscious of the enormous legacy of want that has been left by the previous state Labor government of Western Australia. Unfortunately, as a result of the dispute between the teachers and the state government, we now have the situation where the interests of students are being sacrificed by a dispute that could have been resolved a long time ago had the state government been more reasonable in its approach with the teachers.

PARA.TAB: I am conscious of the enormous number of parents in my electorate—particularly those who have students in year 12, because that is their final year in the Western Australian education system—who are unfortunately suffering the consequences of the industrial actions that have been triggered by what is essentially a heavy-handed approach by the state Liberal government, coming as it has after years of neglect under the previous Labor governments of Premiers Burke, Dowding and Lawrence.

I mention Premier Lawrence, who is now a member of this parliament, because she was the minister for education at a time that there was an education ministers conference in Darwin. From recollection, she went to that conference with about three people in her retinue and was absolutely staggered to find that the Commonwealth component of this conference involved a huge army, or caravanserai, of people from the ministry of education in Canberra. The reason she was staggered by this was the simple fact, as she pointed out in the media, that the Commonwealth government does not teach one single person. Yet they had this huge swag of people choofing into Darwin on the public purse, at a time when resources for education, around the nation, were under pressure.

Firstly, in speaking to this bill, I would like to acknowledge the tremendous contribution that the non-government schools make alongside their government counterparts within my electorate. I have been conscious, from my own particular experiences with those schools, of the tremendous dedication and sense of service that is inculcated in the people who are responsible for the education, the administration and, of course, the other services that go hand in hand with the schools.

I would also like to reflect on the way in which the standing of teachers has declined in our community, probably as a result of the decline in their income in relation to the rest of the community. In dealing with this bill, which attempts to look at a range of issues relating to the education of children within our community, I think it is important to consider that in any society the young are probably the most valuable components because of their obvious influence in the future on the wellbeing and the progress of the economy and our society. The amount of resources devoted to their education is obviously going to be a matter of great concern. In any particular system, whether it has a Labor government or it has coalition government, the standing of teachers, who are after all responsible for guiding and educating our youngsters as they move through the education system, must be something of extreme importance.

I am a father of two school aged children and I am particularly concerned about the way in which the standing of teachers has declined and the way in which they have been treated in recent years. My electorate is probably one of the fastest growing in Australia. I am going to have by election time about 90,000 people on the roll and there are certainly about 140,000 to 150,000 people who live in the area. My electorate also happens to have the greatest concentration of young children in the country, in particular five- to 15-year-olds, obviously the age group that is the biggest consumer of education services in the school system. As the member, I not only ought to but I do have a very significant interest in the way in which our schools are going, the way in which the education system is performing and in particular the relationship between the Commonwealth and state governments over the allocation of the valuable education resources to our schools.

I must say in relation to the dispute in Western Australia that I have been very disappointed in the way in which that has developed. I took the trouble to make a statement and send it to the schools because I was conscious that teachers and those responsible for administering the schools ought to know exactly where their local member stood. I wrote that our electorate is the fastest growing in Australia and the pressure on our schools and teachers is increasing exponentially with that growth. Coping with the speed of change is not easy but it is essential for the future of education in Western Australia, as it is around the country. Teachers are entrusted with up to 12 years of the major parts of our children's lives, in particular that key early period of education, and the bill deals with the aspects of literacy and early education in its provisions. I believe teachers are dedicated, caring professionals who continually carry the wellbeing of their student charges at the forefront of their educational activities. Before I went into parliament I was a member of the Western Australian police force—

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good one too.

—Thank you, I appreciate that. Teachers, along with nurses and police officers, are probably the most selfless members of our community's public service. I do not mean to demean the role played by other public servants, because they all provide a service to our community, but I think that people in those three key areas carry an enormous amount of the burden of the interaction between the most critical parts of our community's activities and functions, and in particular in relation to the key components of state government funding they are probably the most critical areas—education, health and law enforcement services. Teachers, like policemen, nurses and those in medical services, must be held in high regard by our community for the vital developmental role they play in the lives of children. To underpay them for this service is to undervalue their role in our community.

PARA.TAB: I say that in all sincerity. In the economic assessment of each person's contribution to our community, the role that teachers play must surely occupy a far more important status than their remuneration would indicate. It is quite ridiculous that teachers and schools seem to be continually at the dog end of the allocation of valuable resources, when you consider the importance of their role not only in the education of our children but also as providers of that institutional influence within our communities at large.

I know from my contacts within the community that teachers, by and large, put in hours and efforts far beyond their mere physical presence in schools. The pressures faced by teachers, including rising class sizes in some schools, could be compared to those of an actor appearing on stage for many hours a day, as opposed to putting on a performance once in the evening or the afternoon. That is the extent of the pressure that teachers have to put up with every day in their teaching—or, as they call it, the chalk board front end of the system.

The teaching profession has been the subject of misguided policy by both Labor and Liberal administrations. Where adequate increases in remuneration were warranted, which would have reflected teachers' standing in the community, previous Labor governments substituted extra trade-offs in conditions of employment. Unfortunately, the Liberal government is now seeking to remove some of these trade-offs, and offering a small increase in salaries in exchange.

Many teachers work in schools in which dilapidated facilities are not conducive to pride in their work and effective teaching methods. As it should be, education is one of the biggest items in the Western Australian state budget, as I imagine it is around the country. It is time that the government overhauled the education system to reflect not only the standing of teachers in the community but also the genuine desire to have our children taught in schools which are pleasant, safe and learning-conducive environments.

It is a subject of some concern, and even of distress, that in many schools there are temporary classrooms which are constructed of materials that, in the Western Australian summertime, produce quite extraordinary temperature ranges. This is particularly so in the northern parts of the state, but also applies to the metropolitan areas.

A couple of years ago when temperatures went up quite markedly, I took the trouble to contact the RSPCA. Children, parents and teachers had complained about the temperatures in some of these classrooms, which were in coastal areas. Temperatures in those classrooms were almost up to 50 degrees during the day. I rang the RSPCA because I believed that, if somebody had let a pet animal into such an environment, the RSPCA would come out and remove it.

It was true. If somebody had rung them up and said, `The temperature in this room is 50 degrees plus,' they would have been obliged to come in and remove the animal. Yet our children were, and are still, obliged to put up with these conditions. Not only is this inhumane, but it is hardly likely to assist the better education of the children, or the better performance of their teachers. It is coming towards summer now.

Governments, both Labor and Liberal, said that they were introducing air cooling and airconditioning into these particular classrooms, but that this would take some time to take effect in the coastal plain, including Perth. It is ludicrous that in many cases we are still waiting for this basic environmental conditioning, to allow kids to be able to get on with learning.

I support teachers; I support quality education in Western Australia and in Australia. I support a negotiated settlement to the current industrial dispute—which reflects the importance of teaching to the families in the northern suburbs. During the recent tremors of this industrial dispute, there was a particular day when teachers had a stop-work meeting to consider the government's offer. Teachers attending that meeting were given a pay cut of one day, even though many of them missed only two hours. In some of the schools in my electorate they went back to school and resumed their normal responsibilities, albeit with a two-hour gap. Yet they were docked one day's pay.

To my way of thinking, that is not only grossly unfair but, I think, undermines the relationship between the community and the teachers—and, of course, the government. It seemed to me something of a concern that teachers were treated in such a heavy-handed fashion at a time when there was an impasse between the state government, with its pay offer, and the state schoolteachers union, which has raised a number of considerations which it considers important in response.

I have often conducted visits to the schools in my electorate and, of course, have discovered that in some of them—one of the classic cases is the Wanneroo Senior High School—conditions in which teachers and students must work are less than acceptable. In my view, the preventive maintenance program of the education ministry in Western Australia needs to be considerably beefed up.

I recollect that a couple of years ago, back when I first became a member of this House, the then Labor government had allocated something like $22,000 for the preventive maintenance program when, in my electorate, in the Joondalup district as it was then called, there was about $700,000 of preventative maintenance work required to be undertaken. We had the silly situation where we found that a great chunk of that $22,000 was taken up by the building management authority in just inspecting the cooling and ventilation systems in the various schools.

Another aspect in the relationship between government and non-government schools, which has been raised by this particular bill, is the fact that government schools have obligations to educate and to look after particular students, notwithstanding their difficulties or their particular behavioural problems. This is where we have a situation in my electorate, with its great concentration of youngsters, where we have seen quite clearly the retention rate rise or progressively go up as the unemployment situation has deteriorated in the country and in the state.

We have seen the situation where students who otherwise would have been in work, out of the school system, were left back in there basically twiddling their thumbs because they had nowhere else to go. This has led to situations where teachers have been placed in the unfortunate situation of having to deal with disruptive or difficult students without the proper assistance of adequate social workers and other support that would assist them to be able to deal with those types of problems. For instance, at one particular senior high school, there were 14 clearly problem students who were causing disruption within the classrooms—something for which they had to accept responsibility—but unfortunately they did not have the sort of back-up that they ought to be entitled to as a consequence.

I might say that, in all of this dispute, the focus has been purely and simply on the question of a particular pay rate without examining some of the aspects of the implications for the students themselves. I might just point out some of the trade-offs that are being proposed: there will be staffing meetings out of school instructional time, with implications for students and less time for marking and preparation out of instructional hours; the hours of instruction that students receive will increase with no extra staffing to alleviate the extra workload, and less marking and preparation may result in a decline in the quality of teaching; local merit selection of staff will replace centrally controlled transfer system so that teachers seeking transfer to another school will spend more time on preparing a resume at the expense of marking and preparation for the benefit of students; and there may be some aspects of nepotism in some schools.

There is an area which could be developed to the betterment of the interests of students. Unfortunately, because of the way in which this whole issue has been developed by the education department and, in particular, the Minister for Education in WA, this has now become a subject of contention, where otherwise it could have been a subject for the betterment or progressive development of our school system.

In relation to the staffing profile, schools receive a national personnel budget allocation for all teaching and support staff. The implications are that schools may sacrifice highly paid, experienced teachers for lower paid, inexperienced teachers or support staff.
